headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: First question is actually about Neg Reg, but actually, the other team, the foreign medical schools' team. Is there anything that came out of that language or out of those professions that you think will affect your business in any way or the competition?
componenttext: First question is actually about Neg Reg, but actually, the other team, the foreign medical schools' team. Is there anything that came out of that language or out of those professions that you think will affect your business in any way or the competition? And then maybe just as part of that, is there anything changing or different on the competitive landscape for Ross?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of the negotiated rule-making sessions there, and again, we were honored to have Dr. Nancy Perry as one of the team members. When it's in flux, there's nothing to really comment on, so we won't. And in terms of increased competition, no, we
componenttext: Yes. In terms of the negotiated rule-making sessions there, and again, we were honored to have Dr. Nancy Perry as one of the team members. When it's in flux, there's nothing to really comment on, so we won't. And in terms of increased competition, no, we really haven't seen significant levels of new competition. Ross University School of Medicine is now providing more new physicians to the United States residency system than any other school. And by the way, this past year, we vaulted to the number one ranking for African-American physician, number three ranking for Hispanic-American physician, number one ranking for Primary Care physician. So clearly, there's a need and we're hoping to fulfill that need. But the level of competition -- certainly, there are plenty of competition but I don't see material change in that competitive dynamic.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then one for Rick. It's about margins, Rick. Usually, your third quarter margins are a bit higher than your second quarter margins. The second quarter margins were pretty high but I guess there's also some influences on the business, i.e, Fanor and so
componenttext: And then one for Rick. It's about margins, Rick. Usually, your third quarter margins are a bit higher than your second quarter margins. The second quarter margins were pretty high but I guess there's also some influences on the business, i.e, Fanor and some others. Is it fair to assume that, sequentially, margins will be better in the third versus the second?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I characterized that usually, the first and fourth quarter margins are little bit lower than the second and the third. So my expectation would be that our margins in the third quarter shouldn't be that dissimilar from what we've had this quarter,
componenttext: I guess I characterized that usually, the first and fourth quarter margins are little bit lower than the second and the third. So my expectation would be that our margins in the third quarter shouldn't be that dissimilar from what we've had this quarter, then they should go down in the fourth quarter.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is about persistence. DVU's persistence in particular was up quite a bit. Could you talk about the sustainability of persistence and opportunity for increasing persistence?
componenttext: My question is about persistence. DVU's persistence in particular was up quite a bit. Could you talk about the sustainability of persistence and opportunity for increasing persistence?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are very focused on that across all our schools, including DeVry University that you mentioned. And there are things that we do inside the classroom, and there are things we do outside the classroom. And you can have the greatest curriculum in the
componenttext: Yes. We are very focused on that across all our schools, including DeVry University that you mentioned. And there are things that we do inside the classroom, and there are things we do outside the classroom. And you can have the greatest curriculum in the world and the greatest professors in the world. And we certainly think very highly of our curriculum and of our professors. But if you have that, you don't have the supporting student services to surround the classroom and support the student then especially with working adults students or other non-traditional students in the same deposit. You need both in order to support those students and help them to succeed, and persist and graduate. And that's why we are investing in areas like Student Central, which provides the kinds of support services in a very clear, easy-to-access kind of format for our students, and many other sort of curriculum changes and academic changes as well to keep that focus. So when we talk about investments, this is one of the most important areas that we're constantly looking for ideas from our professors and from our service people. Give us ideas, give us projects, so we can pile the capacity to invest in. Those are the highest-return projects that we can invest in. So those are the kinds of things that we're doing to keep working on persistence.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, could you talk about some of that quantitatively? I'm asking, persistence was up significantly year-over-year in DVU. I'm asking is there anything unusual about the elevation? Do you think you can continue to improve on this? Will DVU's persistenc
componenttext: Daniel, could you talk about some of that quantitatively? I'm asking, persistence was up significantly year-over-year in DVU. I'm asking is there anything unusual about the elevation? Do you think you can continue to improve on this? Will DVU's persistence continue to rise sort of near term and intermediate term?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's certainly our goal that the persistence can continue to rise. But I don't have specific numbers to give you, Andrew. But yes, that is our goal that persistence can, and that is our goal that it will continue to rise.
componenttext: It's certainly our goal that the persistence can continue to rise. But I don't have specific numbers to give you, Andrew. But yes, that is our goal that persistence can, and that is our goal that it will continue to rise.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think labor markets, when they improve, will be a headwind to persistence?
componenttext: And do you think labor markets, when they improve, will be a headwind to persistence?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It could be. But I don't think that so much so that we won't be able to continue to grow the enrollments at our universities. And that's why I sort of provided that example. And it's just the example that I have from a very strong period of the 90s. Even
componenttext: It could be. But I don't think that so much so that we won't be able to continue to grow the enrollments at our universities. And that's why I sort of provided that example. And it's just the example that I have from a very strong period of the 90s. Even though the unemployment rate went down, the economy got stronger, we were still able to continue to grow our enrollments.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're pretty confident on the direction of persistence.
componenttext: It sounds like you're pretty confident on the direction of persistence.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Ariel Sokol with Wedbush.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Ariel Sokol with Wedbush.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So a question regarding acquisition, you paid down debt in the quarter. And it looks like you're almost done with the last one, so a couple of questions. One, what does the pipeline look regarding future acquisitions and how may it have changed over the p
componenttext: So a question regarding acquisition, you paid down debt in the quarter. And it looks like you're almost done with the last one, so a couple of questions. One, what does the pipeline look regarding future acquisitions and how may it have changed over the past couple of months? And two, is the regulatory environment and perhaps gainful employment a variable for either you as the buyer or alternatively, is it a variable for potential sellers that you're having conversations with?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We're, certainly, looking at acquisitions all the time. And we feel that we built over the last couple of years a very, very strong function there of internal resources and external resources to assess potential mergers, acquisitions, to do very, very tho
componenttext: We're, certainly, looking at acquisitions all the time. And we feel that we built over the last couple of years a very, very strong function there of internal resources and external resources to assess potential mergers, acquisitions, to do very, very thorough due diligence and then to apply very focused acquisition integration once the school becomes part of the DeVry family. And so we feel very good about those resources, in our track record in this regard, and that we continue to look for acquisitions in the future. One of the things that I commented on recently in Education Day was over the last couple of years, we are sort of building the framework for the house. And now we largely built that, and the focus is shifting a little bit more to kind of filling in the framework that we built. So those are the kinds of acquisitions that we might see to continue filling out at the international framework, continue filling out at the pre-baccalaureate level and those kinds of things. In terms of an impact from the current discussions that are going on in negotiated rule-making process, I can't say that I've seen them have a significant impact one way or the other in our review of potential acquisitions.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Trace Urdan with Signal Hill.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Trace Urdan with Signal Hill.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, you used the Chamberlain example, and I'm returning to this because you kind of open the door here. But you used the Chamberlain example, which is a terrific example and comes in well underneath this 8% threshold that the department is talking abo
componenttext: Daniel, you used the Chamberlain example, and I'm returning to this because you kind of open the door here. But you used the Chamberlain example, which is a terrific example and comes in well underneath this 8% threshold that the department is talking about. But normally, what you talked to us about is the $45,000 that is earned by DeVry graduates, which would fail to meet that threshold. So I'm wondering what you do with that example or how you think about that? Or do you think, when you make that statement that you think common sense will prevail, is it your feeling that the criterion here will move to accommodate schools like DeVry?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Essentially, yes. We think common sense will prevail. And DeVry University founded in 1931, approaching its 80th anniversary, I don't think it's going to suddenly go out of business in its 81st year or whatever. I don't think that there's going to be a pr
componenttext: Essentially, yes. We think common sense will prevail. And DeVry University founded in 1931, approaching its 80th anniversary, I don't think it's going to suddenly go out of business in its 81st year or whatever. I don't think that there's going to be a problem.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you share with us maybe what the lifetime cohort default rate looks like for DeVry?
componenttext: Can you share with us maybe what the lifetime cohort default rate looks like for DeVry?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Lifetime, no, we don't have figures like that to share.
componenttext: Lifetime, no, we don't have figures like that to share.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you know off hand what, including deferments in the cohort default rate, does to the numbers maybe without being specific but just order of magnitude?
componenttext: Do you know off hand what, including deferments in the cohort default rate, does to the numbers maybe without being specific but just order of magnitude?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think we've given information recently in the last couple of months that some people have seen that. And there's an increase, certainly, when you go from two years to three years. But none of our institutions does that, trip any wires or crea
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think we've given information recently in the last couple of months that some people have seen that. And there's an increase, certainly, when you go from two years to three years. But none of our institutions does that, trip any wires or create a major problem. It is something that we're concerned about. It's something that we are actively working with students, with lenders to ensure that we educate students and parents on their responsibilities. These are the kinds of activities that have proven over time to help improve the performance, and we're paying those, the financial obligations, and thereby reducing default rate. And so we continue to manage that. But I want to be very clear to everybody that there's nothing in any sort of rumors that sort of trip the wire or anything like that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So I mean, not to press this point too much but looking at those three-year numbers, which have not had the benefit of being "managed," do you think like those three-year numbers kind of give you a pretty good proxy for what those defaults look like when
componenttext: So I mean, not to press this point too much but looking at those three-year numbers, which have not had the benefit of being "managed," do you think like those three-year numbers kind of give you a pretty good proxy for what those defaults look like when deferments are not included in the calculation, is that fair?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know. And I really just can't comment on that one, Trace, sorry.
componenttext: I don't know. And I really just can't comment on that one, Trace, sorry.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The question about income-based repayment, I know CDR is not really an issue for you. But have you looked at income-based repayment? Can that help you get your cohort default rates even lower? And if you haven't looked at it, do you think it's significant
componenttext: The question about income-based repayment, I know CDR is not really an issue for you. But have you looked at income-based repayment? Can that help you get your cohort default rates even lower? And if you haven't looked at it, do you think it's significant for some of your students? And can you size it all?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we support that. We think it's a good idea. And we support all kinds of creative ideas like that, that can help students, be helpful to students. And yes, I think that would probably be a positive.
componenttext: Yes, we support that. We think it's a good idea. And we support all kinds of creative ideas like that, that can help students, be helpful to students. And yes, I think that would probably be a positive.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Any way to size the percentage of your students that could avoid defaults through an income-based repayment program?
componenttext: Any way to size the percentage of your students that could avoid defaults through an income-based repayment program?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: None off the top of my head. Sorry, Paul, I just don't have a number to give you off the top of my head.
componenttext: None off the top of my head. Sorry, Paul, I just don't have a number to give you off the top of my head.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And next to your question is from the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.
componenttext: And next to your question is from the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with the question that probably would've been the first one out of the queue, if it's four, five years ago [ph], which is just how enrollments went in the fall start for the younger high school population versus the working adult student
componenttext: I wanted to start with the question that probably would've been the first one out of the queue, if it's four, five years ago [ph], which is just how enrollments went in the fall start for the younger high school population versus the working adult students?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of our high school-- I got to thank you for that question. Thank you for bring us back to just talking about students and education. It is refreshing. I would say that, as an overarching point on that, Corey, we do feel very good about -- we like
componenttext: In terms of our high school-- I got to thank you for that question. Thank you for bring us back to just talking about students and education. It is refreshing. I would say that, as an overarching point on that, Corey, we do feel very good about -- we like the Traditional Out of High School Traditional College-Age Students segment, and we like the Working Adult segment. And we really like the fact that our strategy encompasses offerings and services to both of those overall segments of students. And we find a lot of synergy and a lot of benefit in having programs that respond to the needs of both those segments, not just one or the other. We are actually investing and focusing even more of the weight on the High School segment. And we expect to see synergies from our K-12 program. And Advanced Academics, in fact, is helping that. And also, the fact that we run high school programs, high school recruiting programs, high school educational programs, not just at DeVry University but also at Chamberlain College of Nursing, and at Apollo College and Western Career College that really are additive to the whole. So we feel good about the high school program. And I think we'll see continued improvements there. And Rick, do you want to add anything to the high school question?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, the only thing I would add is that when you look at our enrolment growth like we disclosed back in December, we've seen a nice balance in the growth rates between on-site and online. If you go back five years ago, you would have seen on-site
componenttext: Yes. I guess, the only thing I would add is that when you look at our enrolment growth like we disclosed back in December, we've seen a nice balance in the growth rates between on-site and online. If you go back five years ago, you would have seen on-site actually experiencing some declines and online really driving some of the growth. Whereas now, given our best of both philosophy, we're seeing growth both in online and on-site in pretty equal proportions.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And is online still primarily a working adult model or is the younger traditional students interested in online as well now?
componenttext: And is online still primarily a working adult model or is the younger traditional students interested in online as well now?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's still primarily the working adult. But increasingly, the traditional college-age students coming out of high school is taking online courses. So it's really a mix and match. And I think that's really the best of both, online and on-site, is where the
componenttext: It's still primarily the working adult. But increasingly, the traditional college-age students coming out of high school is taking online courses. So it's really a mix and match. And I think that's really the best of both, online and on-site, is where the market's going. That's where the demand from students is going. And we've been saying that for over 10 years. That's why we've never separated the online and the on-site. We never give separate the numbers. We always talked about it in terms of total online course takers, and it's for that very reason. So that's the dynamic that we're seeing.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And I have one other question for Rick. You are helpful at the Education Day. You talked about long-term targets for each of the segments. And can you just put that in perspective? I mean, it's so obvious that you're well above those targets particularly
componenttext: And I have one other question for Rick. You are helpful at the Education Day. You talked about long-term targets for each of the segments. And can you just put that in perspective? I mean, it's so obvious that you're well above those targets particularly in the Business, Technology and Management segment. Will the goal be to meet those targets year in and year out? Or would you consider it a victory if the compound annual growth rate ends up being at those levels in some years, so you're below that rate compounded over this year, when you're going to move well above [ph] the rate?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd said that the success we're having this year, the strong results that have exceeded the goal in fiscal '10, I don't think would lead us to believe that we would then be below that for the next couple of years to average it out, if that's what
componenttext: I guess, I'd said that the success we're having this year, the strong results that have exceeded the goal in fiscal '10, I don't think would lead us to believe that we would then be below that for the next couple of years to average it out, if that's what you're asking. I think we feel good about being able to deliver roughly 20% earnings growth going forward after this year as the base.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we challenge ourselves to continue that, even though we've set a higher bar, you might say.
componenttext: Yes. So we challenge ourselves to continue that, even though we've set a higher bar, you might say.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a question now from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And you have a question now from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, there was a lot of talk of you had really nice margins, and there's talk about some branding and marketing spend that was delayed in the first quarter. And I think it's already been covered in the Q&A today that you're looking for comparable
componenttext: Last quarter, there was a lot of talk of you had really nice margins, and there's talk about some branding and marketing spend that was delayed in the first quarter. And I think it's already been covered in the Q&A today that you're looking for comparable margins, 3Q versus 2Q. But could we go down to the weeds a little bit and talk about some of the investments that you are making currently including marketing?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start and Daniel can add to it. But the investments, when  we talk investments, we're talking both spending that as expense and spending that to capitalize. I mean, the capital spend we've talked about, the Project Delta's a big piece of that
componenttext: Sure. Let me start and Daniel can add to it. But the investments, when  we talk investments, we're talking both spending that as expense and spending that to capitalize. I mean, the capital spend we've talked about, the Project Delta's a big piece of that along with the spending within DeVry University for makeovers and expansion and some real estate optimization activities, expansion at Chamberlain, expansion at U.S. Education. The types of things that hit expenses are in the areas of academic quality, branded quality and just growth initiatives. Academic quality would be things like our Student Central rollouts and support behind the Career Services advisors that Daniel mentioned, more student services to work with students throughout the time from they first enrolled to they graduate, our brand quality in terms of the things that Daniel mentioned on Keller awareness, and we launched initiatives at certain locations to really get some resurgence in locations that maybe need a little jumpstart, and then growth and adding more admissions advisors in online, for example. The more we grow, we need people that can work with the students and advise them upfront. So those are the types of things that we're investing in.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say, I mean, Daniel mentioned earlier that you've really been investing a lot in the past couple of years. And people would mention that you're not showing, perhaps, some of the margin expansion that others had seen and certainly putting tha
componenttext: Is it fair to say, I mean, Daniel mentioned earlier that you've really been investing a lot in the past couple of years. And people would mention that you're not showing, perhaps, some of the margin expansion that others had seen and certainly putting that up now. So is it a nice measured pace now? Or could there potentially be some lumpiness going forward?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're always going to take advantage of opportunities. We're not going to be shy from making investments in academic quality or other quality initiatives, where we think that it's warranted. And so could there be some lumpiness? Without a doubt. We'
componenttext: Well, we're always going to take advantage of opportunities. We're not going to be shy from making investments in academic quality or other quality initiatives, where we think that it's warranted. And so could there be some lumpiness? Without a doubt. We're not managing this for the quarter, we're managing this for the long term. But I think we've proven in field that as we invest and make these investments that they will pay out over the long term. And so when you look at it in a year-to-year basis, we think that, again, should be pretty consistent in terms of our 20% earnings growth on a compound annual basis.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You guys did a nice job of talking ahead of time about seasonality in the first half of the fiscal year with regard to the Other Educational Services segment. Anything to look out for in the second half there?
componenttext: You guys did a nice job of talking ahead of time about seasonality in the first half of the fiscal year with regard to the Other Educational Services segment. Anything to look out for in the second half there?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, if I recall, the third quarter is going to be pretty close to what we saw in the second quarter, the revenue continue to build. But in the fourth quarter, you do have -- I think June, where there's some weeks where we don't have classes, so you e
componenttext: I think, if I recall, the third quarter is going to be pretty close to what we saw in the second quarter, the revenue continue to build. But in the fourth quarter, you do have -- I think June, where there's some weeks where we don't have classes, so you end up having the revenue not be as large in the fourth quarter because of that. In Advanced Academics, for example, high school ending in early June.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a question now from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.
componenttext: And you have a question now from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, can you give us any sense, as we think about a huge margin expansion in the DeVry University segment, how much of that over the last few years has driven by mix shift and growth of your Online business? And secondly, how much of that has been dri
componenttext: I guess, can you give us any sense, as we think about a huge margin expansion in the DeVry University segment, how much of that over the last few years has driven by mix shift and growth of your Online business? And secondly, how much of that has been driven by this whole concept of the co-located schools? I think it's in your company expense, the paying some rent expense or other payment to that segment to use those facilities?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would give it a shot here. Rick certainly have more color. But I would say that the biggest driver's operating leverage. In terms of mix shift, I think that slowed down as a percentage over the last little while relative to what it's been a couple
componenttext: Well, I would give it a shot here. Rick certainly have more color. But I would say that the biggest driver's operating leverage. In terms of mix shift, I think that slowed down as a percentage over the last little while relative to what it's been a couple of years ago. Co-locations are a wonderful strategy. They're paying off in excess of our expectation. And so we continue to look for those opportunities. I just mentioned four Chamberlain co-locations here in a period of about a year. And we're also looking at Apollo College and Western Career College opportunities to co-locate with Chamberlain and with DeVry University. So all of those, I think, are good factors.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add that online has got good attractive incremental margins, it's by the nature of online. But on-site, given where we are today, as we, either through the co-locations utilizing the facility or through the strong enrollment results we'v
componenttext: Yes. I would just add that online has got good attractive incremental margins, it's by the nature of online. But on-site, given where we are today, as we, either through the co-locations utilizing the facility or through the strong enrollment results we've had, where you have students sit in empty chairs within a facility, speak more [ph] that's already existing that leads to that strong incremental pullthrough that we've been experiencing here short term. And we still have available capacity as we go forward. So for the not-too-distant future, we should continue to see good leverage.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you've laid out the long-term plans at your Investor Day, it seemed to include not only moderate pricing growth for the segment but also, clearly, the expectation of some moderate leverage as you grow. Can you give us any sense as to what the upp
componenttext: And when you've laid out the long-term plans at your Investor Day, it seemed to include not only moderate pricing growth for the segment but also, clearly, the expectation of some moderate leverage as you grow. Can you give us any sense as to what the upper bounds might be? Obviously, today, with the terrific growth, it seems like it's been pretty easy the last couple of years. But it's got to be getting somewhat tougher particularly if one expects enrollments to slow down maybe in fiscal '11 or '12, towards that long-term target. I guess, are you comfortable with all the leverage as you see them, that you can continue to get over the next several years with a start [ph] on this fiscal year?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. I would say that it -- we've been working pretty hard over the last couple of years. And our people have worked incredibly hard. And really, these results are a testament to the teams' hard work. And if we continue to do that and keep the focu
componenttext: Sure, Gary. I would say that it -- we've been working pretty hard over the last couple of years. And our people have worked incredibly hard. And really, these results are a testament to the teams' hard work. And if we continue to do that and keep the focus on our students and academic success, we really don't see any reason that we can't continue to achieve the targets that we've laid out at Investor Day and at Education Day. And while there may be something that get a little bit harder, there are some other things that we haven't really even pulled the lever on. And the earlier question that Amy asked about Project Delta is an example of that. I mean, we're investing in this new system for a reason, better service and better productivity for our students. And we haven't rolled out yet, so we would expect that to be a lever. We're certainly gearing up and looking for other ways to be more efficient and more effective in many areas throughout the operations. So I think that, that's one of the nature of management, you're always finding, you pursued this particular initiative and that kind of maybe ran its course but it continues to pay off for you. And then you move on to the next one. And we see plenty of opportunities here to keep the good thing going.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you mentioned earlier you might do some more actual branding work with Keller. And I know that was something that got mentioned a couple of times at the Investor Day, a larger percent of your ad spend on branding. Can you give us a sense as to wha
componenttext: I think you mentioned earlier you might do some more actual branding work with Keller. And I know that was something that got mentioned a couple of times at the Investor Day, a larger percent of your ad spend on branding. Can you give us a sense as to what type of format are you talking television commercials like we've seen a couple of our competitors doing? Or how are you thinking about more time on branding?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. And we'd like to -- instead of using that word, we're trying to use the word identity. And so that's really what I was talking about. But yes, we're building the identity, building the awareness of Keller. One of the things I think we talked about b
componenttext: Sure. And we'd like to -- instead of using that word, we're trying to use the word identity. And so that's really what I was talking about. But yes, we're building the identity, building the awareness of Keller. One of the things I think we talked about back at the Education Day was down the undergraduates side. DeVry University has quite a high awareness, and we need to work on its consideration. Whereas Keller, specifically the Graduate School of DeVry University, has -- when you know about it, you have very high consideration. It's just none of the people know about, so we need to increase the awareness. So that's the strategy there. In terms of some of the tools that we'd use to increase that awareness and identity, we would use a very -- because we know not a lot of new inventions under the sun here. We've used the same sorts of identity-building activities that traditional universities you might see, billboards or television ads or online ad. Certainly, the social media, social marketing is a newer area. And we are very well versed in the opportunities there. So those are all the kinds of opportunities that we have. One opportunity we don't have that some of the traditionals have, a big-time sports team. We can't pull that lever real hard. But pretty much everything else, you'll see us doing.Listen, thanks everyone for your questions. And our next conference call, which is April 22, we will be reporting the third quarter financial results and the spring enrolment numbers. So we would like to thank everyone on this call for your continued support of DeVry. Thanks very much. Have a great afternoon.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation in today's conference. And at this time, this concludes the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have yourselves a wonderful day or evening.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation in today's conference. And at this time, this concludes the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have yourselves a wonderful day or evening.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fiscal 2010 Second Quarter Conference Call. My name is Jeremy, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the presentation over to Ms. Joan Bates,
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fiscal 2010 Second Quarter Conference Call. My name is Jeremy, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the presentation over to Ms. Joan Bates, Senior Director of Investor Relations and Media.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy. With me today from DeVry management are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Before we begin, please be advised that statements made on this conferen
componenttext: Thank you, Jeremy. With me today from DeVry management are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Before we begin, please be advised that statements made on this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements subject to the Safe Harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements generally can be identified by phrases such as DeVry, Inc. or its management has a view, objective or outlook, or that management believes, expects, anticipate, foresee, forecast, estimate or other words or phrases of similar importance. Actual results may differ materially from those projected or implied. Potential risks and uncertainties and other factors that could cause results to differ are described more fully in Item 1A, Risk Factors in DeVry's most recent annual report on Form 10-K for the year ending June 30, 2009, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on July 26, 2009. Telephone and webcast replay for the call are available until February 9, 2010. To access the replay, please refer to today's press release for information.  Daniel Hamburger will begin today's call with a quick overview followed by a review of the financial results by Rick Gunst. Daniel will then provide an operations update before opening up the call for your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Daniel.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joan, and thank you, all very much for joining us for our Fiscal 2010 Second Quarter Conference Call. And since we saw many of you at our Education Day in November and today's announcement doesn't include enrollment results, we'll make an effort t
componenttext: Thanks, Joan, and thank you, all very much for joining us for our Fiscal 2010 Second Quarter Conference Call. And since we saw many of you at our Education Day in November and today's announcement doesn't include enrollment results, we'll make an effort to be brief this afternoon and get to your questions.So we're pleased to announce that the continued execution of our growth in diversification strategy and our focus on investing in academic quality has produced successful student outcomes and another quarter of strong financial results. In the increase that we saw in enrollments in December translated into exceptional revenue growth in the quarter, which drove margin improvement and record earnings. At the same time, we continued to invest in our programs and student services to drive future growth. At DeVry's home office, this quarter has been a busy one for us as we recently moved into our new offices in Downers Grove in Oak Brook, Illinois, and we moved out our data center to its new location as well. Our new home office is a co-location with the DeVry University Center and houses a classroom of the future. The new offices are designed to be open and collaborative with state-of-the-art amenities for our employees and are another part of our strategy to be the employer of choice in education and we'd like to invite you to come visit us when you can.I'd like to spend a few minutes here on our expectations for the rest of 2010 and beyond in the context of the overarching economic conditions that we're seeing. Because there certainly are some optimistic signs that the worst of this recession is behind us. But with the government announcement, for example, the 85,000 jobs were lost in December, it remains clear that meaningful economic recovery is not a foregoing conclusion here in 2010. As I outlined during our Education Day, we believe DeVry is well-positioned in both good and bad times.Our confidence is bolstered by two factors. But first, our operating philosophy namely that “Quality Leads to Growth”. At DeVry, our institutions educate students  for positions across a variety of industries, but they have one thing in common. Each provides high-quality programs and services to our students. And as we continue to invest in quality, academic outcomes improve. The continued success of our students drives enrollment and retention, which leads to financial growth, and this is true in both good times and in bad times. And we, in turn, put those earnings right back to work by investing them in the quality of our programs. A case in point, we're planning to invest over $100 million this year in capital expenditures on our programs, services and facilities. In today's world of state budget cuts and declining endowment, this investment is an example of the important role that private sector schools, like DeVry, are playing in today's educational system. And the second factor is our diversification strategy, which has us well-positioned to deliver consistent and sustainable growth, again, through both good and bad economic times. Some of our operations are co-cyclical, like Becker, which has been negatively affected by the weak economy's. At the same time, schools like those of U.S. Education are more countercyclical. And in addition, DeVry has schools like, such as Chamberlain College of Nursing and Ross University, that are entirely non-cyclical. In fact, DeVry is the only publicly-traded education provider that has a medical school or a veterinary school. So taken as a whole, the DeVry family of schools is best characterized as non-cyclical. And so given our philosophy of quality leads to growth, and our ability to mitigate risks through our diverse family of schools, I believe we'll continue to experience sustainable growth when the economy recovers.And just an illustration of this, I'd like to share with you how our largest school, DeVry University, grew during the strongest economic recovery in the postwar era, the 90s. And for this, please refer to the chart that you'll find in today's press release. Because if you take a look at that chart, you'll see that at the end of the recession in 1992 and moving forward for 10 years in 2001, the job market improved with unemployment falling from a high of 7.4%, down to 4.2% over that period. And taking a look at DeVry University's total enrollment over that same period, our enrollment continued to grow, in fact, the rate of growth increased. And keep in mind that that was in the 90s, when we weren't as diversified as we are today. I think a lot of people think we're more countercyclical than we really are, and this example demonstrates that we are able to grow in an economic recovery. And so with that introduction, let me turn the call over to Rick for the financial results.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to take the next several minutes to highlight our strong financial performance for the second quarter and first half of fiscal 2010. I'm pleased and encouraged to see the very positive impact from ou
componenttext: Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to take the next several minutes to highlight our strong financial performance for the second quarter and first half of fiscal 2010. I'm pleased and encouraged to see the very positive impact from our investments in academic quality and customer service, which have resulted in strong revenue growth, along with significantly-improved margins and profitability. Record quarterly revenue of $473 million was up about 28% versus prior year. This is primarily organic growth as we've anniversaried the U.S. Education acquisition in September, with revenues still up 25% in the quarter, excluding our more recent acquisition of DeVry Brazil. Revenue to the first half of the fiscal year was up about 34% and 25% when you exclude both DeVry Brazil and U.S. Education.Net income and earnings per share were both up about 69% in the quarter and 64% year-to-date. Earnings per share were $1 in the quarter, marking the first time we've broken through the dollar threshold. It's also interesting to note that our earnings per share were only $0.61 for the entire year in fiscal 2006, just 3.5 years ago. The pretax income margin for the first half was 21%, up 470 basis points versus the 16.3% margin achieved a year ago. Now fiscal 2010 is really shaping up to be a breakthrough year, and we expect to significantly surpass our historical peak margin of 17.1% this year. These results were driven by the excellent enrollment growth and retention results across our schools, while our Professional Education segment continues to be negatively impacted by the economy. The financials reflect the power of operating leverage, which is helping drive the significant profitability improvement. For your reference, second quarter results include expense related to share-based payments of approximately $2.1 million pretax or $1.8 million net of tax, a bit higher than last year. Our overall effective tax rate was 33.6% in the quarter and 32.9% year-to-date, up from the 30.4% rate for full-year fiscal 2009, primarily due to the continued increase in domestic source income.For a perspective, we're now paying over $100 million in federal and state taxes on an annualized basis. Cost of educational service expense increased by 20% versus prior year in the quarter. And student services and administrative expense increased by 17%, both grew on a double-digit rate, but less than the revenue growth with or without the acquisitions. We continue to make prudent, targeted investments while still delivering leverage and efficiencies.With that, as a highlight, let me walk you through some of the operating segment results, which are further detailed in our earnings release. First, the Business, Technology, and Management Segment achieved a very strong top- and bottom-line results. Revenue was up 26% versus prior year in the quarter and 25% year-to-date, driven by the strong enrollment growth and increased retention driven by our focus on student services. The segment operating income of $78 million in the quarter and $134 million year-to-date more than doubled versus prior year. This improvement was driven by revenue growth and a resulting operating leverage. The segment margin was 24.9% in the quarter and 22.5% year-to-date. While we're continuing to make investments to support academic quality and customer service, our incremental earnings flow through for the segment has been over 60% year-to-date. This shows the power of operating leverage on our cost base from the very strong top-line growth. Within the Medical and Healthcare segment, revenue was up 28% in the quarter, driven by the enrollment growth and pricing at Ross University and Chamberlain College of Nursing, along with continued good results at Apollo College and Western Career College. Second quarter operating income for the segment of $31.2 million was up 17% versus last year. The margin was a bit lower than prior year driven by business mix within the segment with the addition of U.S. Education and very strong growth at Chamberlain, both which have lower margins than Ross University.Our Professional Education segment results continue to reflect the impact of the soft economy on the accounting and finance professions. Revenue was down 6.3% in the quarter and down 4.6% year-to-date versus last year. Operating income was down about 28% in the quarter and 21% year-to-date. Once again, we don't expect performance to improve materially in calendar 2010, or really until the economy recovery takes hold and positively impacts hiring and training within the accounting and finance professions.We are closely managing costs in the short term and recently completed the consolidation of a number of positions in the marketing and sales area. But at the same time, we're planning to cease the opportunity when the industry does rebound. Lastly, results of our Other Educational Services segment reflect the top line contributions to growth from Advanced Academics in DeVry Brazil. The segment delivered operating income of $700,000 in the second quarter following the first quarter loss due to the seasonal flow of the segment.Shifting to the balance sheet, our cash and marketable security balance was $334 million at the end of the second quarter compared to $263 million last year. Cash flow from operations for the first half was $267 million versus $139 million last year, driven by our improved earnings and working capital.These strong cash results enable us to continue to decrease our outstanding debt to $45 million, down from $155 million a year ago and $105 million last quarter and also invest back in the business as capital spending to the first half of the year was $62 million versus $25 million spent last year. The spending has been focused on Project Delta, which we believe will further enhance our ability to provide best-in-class service to our students. As well as on facility improvements within DeVry University and U.S. Education, an expansion within Ross University and Chamberlain College of Nursing. We're committed to investing in educational technology and capacity needed to serve our students, so total capital spending is still expected to exceed $100 million this fiscal year.Our net accounts receivable balance actually decreased to $135 million versus a $138 million last year. In fact, if you exclude DeVry Brazil, our net receivable balance would have decreased by $7 million. Receivables per account within DeVry University were down compared to the higher balances last year during the conversion of our financial aid processing system, but they were also lower than our balances two years ago. While we had some issues initially, the new processing system is having a positive impact. So this is a good example of how our investments in new technology are paying off and improve customer service and productivity. Year-to-date, our bad debt rate increased slightly versus last year to 3.2%, driven by the U.S. Education and DeVry Brazil acquisitions. We have not experienced any deterioration with bad debt in our legacy operations. So our receivables per students are down and our bad debt rate is essentially unchanged. We see this as another marker of quality and would like to recognize the outstanding performance of our teams in managing this area, particularly during these tough economic times.Finally, during the quarter we completed the execution of our second share repurchase program, buying back $50 million of common stock over the last year or about 1 million shares at an average cost of $48.67 per share. Our Board of Directors approved the third repurchase program in November of $50 million. We have not commenced this program yet since we have been in the close trading window, but plan to begin repurchasing once again when the window opens up later this week.So that concludes my overview of the very strong results for the first half of the year. We're obviously off to a tremendous start and are confident in our ability to deliver a strong top and bottom line results for the balance of the fiscal year, all driven by academic quality. As we've said in the past, our long-term financial objective is to deliver earnings per share growth of roughly 20% per year. Our strong first half performance puts us in a position to exceed this goal as we believe earnings will continue to grow in excess of 20% over the balance of this fiscal year. Now let me turn the call back over to Daniel for some more color on the operating results.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Let me begin net operating review with our Business Technology and Management segment, which is DeVry University and is Keller Graduate School of Management. And since we didn't have a conference call in December when we have reported the
componenttext: Thank you, Rick. Let me begin net operating review with our Business Technology and Management segment, which is DeVry University and is Keller Graduate School of Management. And since we didn't have a conference call in December when we have reported the fall enrollment, I'd like to comment on the strong growth that DeVry University experienced during that period with new undergraduate enrollment of more than 19% and total undergraduate enrollment rising nearly 23%.These results and our continued strong execution position us well for the remainder of 2010. And it's important to note that we're seeing broad-based contributions at DeVry University from online and on-site in both graduate and undergraduate and across our business, technology and healthcare program. This quarter, DeVry University continued to focus on its positioning as the career university. Over the coming months, we plan to hire additional career advisors beyond the 150 we already have in place. To further improve persistence, we're hiring more student coaches as we implement our innovative Student Central concept across our campus location. Student Central brings all key services together in one place and proactively supports our students from the time they enroll to when they graduate. Other growth initiatives include our plans to open new locations in Glendale, Arizona and Houston, Texas in the next few months. At Keller Graduate School of Management, total coursetakers in the November session increased more than 16.5% from a year ago. As part of our initiative to increase awareness at Keller, we'll be investing a bit more in the communications campaign. Our goal is to align Keller more closely with our student familiarity with traditional business schools and to reinforce Keller's high-quality reputation. We're very excited for this new campaign and it begins in the spring.Moving on to our Medical and Healthcare segment, at Chamberlain College of Nursing, enrollment in the fall increased 67% and we continue to invest in facilities to meet the huge demand for qualified nurses around the country. In addition to our newest campus in Jacksonville that opened seven months ago, Chamberlain's new Chicago and Crystal City, Virginia locations are on pace to open this summer, pending approvals. And after 80 years, Chamberlain is also moving its St. Louis location to a brand-new building in nearby Maryland Heights. All four of these campuses are co-locations with DeVry University, pretty interesting. In addition, we're launching a new RN to MSN bridge program in July. This program will be part of Chamberlain's expanding online offerings, and it provides a great option for RNs, Registered Nurses, who want to earn a master's degree. And in line with our emphasis on doing well by doing good, Chamberlain's mission in November to Brazil was a great success as Chamberlain partnered with DeVry Brazil to set up a local clinic in the city of Madalena. A second trip is happening this week and we plan on expanding the program to three trips a year, very proud of that. At U.S. Education, that's Apollo College and Western Career College, we continue to invest in new programs and to focus on integration and efficiency. During the quarter, we launched a Physical Therapy Assistant program in Apollo College's Mesa, Arizona campus. We expect to bring this program to other campuses pending approval and we've hired new program directors to support that goal. Now that the integration of Apollo College and Western Career College doing its final phase, we're focusing on expanding student enrollments both on-site and online, and we're also looking at other areas of value creation. As one example, we recently consolidated U.S. Education service centers in Phoenix and its accounting function in our Mission Viejo office that streamlines our operations and supports future expansion. Another example, we're also seeing efficiency through higher capacity utilization. You notice that while we were very well utilized in the mornings, the afternoon and evening classes were less so. So this led us to initiate a program aimed in helping students find the class time that work best with their schedule. The result has been much more evenly dispersed classes in the afternoons and evenings and greater campus utilization.So now let me move to our Professional Education segment, where the economy continues to dramatically affect the accounting and finance fields that Becker serves. During this quarter, Becker's CPA group piloted a 0% financing initiative to help recent college graduates who are most affected by the current job market. The initial results of this program have been pretty promising and could be expanded once we have a chance to thoroughly review the program. In December, at Becker we also signed an exclusive partnership with China Distance Educational Holdings Ltd. to distribute Becker's materials in China. This partnership offers great potential to expand our CPA courses in China and could eventually include our Stalla CFA program as well, a chartered financial analyst. While times are tough, it's tough for Becker's competitors, too. One key advantage for Becker is being part of a diversified organization that can support its long-term growth. Most of Becker's competitors are small and don't have this advantage, so we believe this positions Becker very well for when the accounting and finance fields start to [indiscernible]. And our final segment, Other Educational Services.  As we announced in Education Day, what we have been calling Fanor, we're now calling DeVry Brazil which includes three colleges. There is Fanor, there is Ruy Barbosa and Area 1. Our people in Brazil see tremendous value in the DeVry name and are very excited about the change. We're also in the process of launching several new programs in high demand healthcare fields such as nursing, physiotherapy and nutrition. Classes should be available beginning next month.So to summarize, as you can see, our diversification strategy and our focus on investing in quality continue to lead to growth, strong student academic outcomes and another quarter of solid financial results. The investments we've talked about over the last couple of years are paying off. From time to time, we've heard feedback on occasion, let's say, to be effective, I think you should invest less and show more to your near-term margin, that kind of thing. What we're demonstrating here is that by investing in quality, we're getting great academic outcomes as well as growth and margin. In sum, “Quality Leads to Growth”. And so I'd like to close by thanking the 114,000 students across all DeVry schools. It's truly our privilege to help them achieve their career goals. And I'd also like to thank the 17,000 members of the DeVry family for their dedication to our students and for their vital role that they play in our success. And so with that, Joan, we're happy to take questions.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask a question about Project Delta? And at your Education Day, Dave Pauldine had said that the bulk of the work was going to be done over the next couple of quarters. You've obviously had tremendous results, and so it's hard to kind of decipher
componenttext: Can I just ask a question about Project Delta? And at your Education Day, Dave Pauldine had said that the bulk of the work was going to be done over the next couple of quarters. You've obviously had tremendous results, and so it's hard to kind of decipher here. But I'm just wondering what percentage of that is really student phasing? And have you seen any signs, whatsoever, that there's any productivity disruption as the enrollment counselors kind of become accumulated to the new system?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding Project Delta, we have not launched the bulk of Project Delta. So, no, we haven't seen any impact on the operations because it hasn't launched. And Rick was referring to a part of our overall systems, technology investment, which was in the stud
componenttext: Regarding Project Delta, we have not launched the bulk of Project Delta. So, no, we haven't seen any impact on the operations because it hasn't launched. And Rick was referring to a part of our overall systems, technology investment, which was in the student finance area that we have seen have a positive impact, and to be able to report that our accounts receivable was actually down in this economy. It really does speak to, not only the quality of the fundamental value proposition that students are receiving, but it takes a lot of processing and a lot of customer service to make that happen. So the systems investments that we've made have had a positive impact there. And so as we look forward to implementing Project Delta, we're looking forward to similar types of results. And maybe there was a little misunderstanding there -- and not the next couple of quarters, I'd say it's a little bit longer-term than that. It's several quarters in rolling out. And the thing that I can assure you is that we're not going to roll any system out until it's ready.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then to stay kind of the piece of it that's potentially student phasing, how much is that?
componenttext: Okay, and then to stay kind of the piece of it that's potentially student phasing, how much is that?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you think of Project Delta, if going forward here beyond the piece that we mentioned earlier in two main areas, one is the student information system, the SIS; and the other is the constituent relationship management, the CRM. In some other insti
componenttext: Sure. If you think of Project Delta, if going forward here beyond the piece that we mentioned earlier in two main areas, one is the student information system, the SIS; and the other is the constituent relationship management, the CRM. In some other institutes, they call that customer relationship management, but it's similar concept. Both of those areas have both back office, you might say, as well as student phasing or other constituent phasing components to them. So for example, in the student information system, you tend to think of that as a back office system that helps you keep of all your students and where they are in your program and everything like that. There's also a self-service registration component that flows out of that and that directly is available to students and helps improve service levels. Many students prefer to register themselves rather than talk to anybody, and we want to make that available. So that has both in-house and customization. Likewise, the constituent relationship management directly affects both sides of the coin there. So it's a big project, it's a big investment, we're very excited about the customer service improvements, the student service improvement, and the internal productivity and efficiency that we anticipate from that.

componenttext: I'm wondering if there's anything unusual in the business technology in management margins this quarter. They were much better than what we're expecting. And I guess I'm wondering if that 60% incremental margin is a good target for the rest of the year?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's anything unusual in the quarter. I think what's resulting in the flow through is just the operating leverage that we're able to obtain given the strong enrollment results we announced in December. Our retention sale was very good yea
componenttext: I don't think there's anything unusual in the quarter. I think what's resulting in the flow through is just the operating leverage that we're able to obtain given the strong enrollment results we announced in December. Our retention sale was very good year-over-year. And the course load that we saw deteriorating a little bit has just stabilized. So all those things have added up to improving our revenue numbers, and while we're still investing in operating expenses and academic quality and cost of the instruction, we're getting that flow through.  And for the balance to back half of the year, it should be in that range, and not too far distant from that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can comment at all on the negotiated rule making proceeding them particularly on the gain for employment discussion? And if you could talk a bit about your debt service to income ratios given that that's a hot topic?
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can comment at all on the negotiated rule making proceeding them particularly on the gain for employment discussion? And if you could talk a bit about your debt service to income ratios given that that's a hot topic?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Overall, we see the negotiated rule making as a healthy collaborative process. We think that it's good that there are many, many points of view represented there. And we support that we feel honored, actually, to have a representative and I'm one of the t
componenttext: Overall, we see the negotiated rule making as a healthy collaborative process. We think that it's good that there are many, many points of view represented there. And we support that we feel honored, actually, to have a representative and I'm one of the teams, and we're obviously engaged in both of the teams.  So that's part of the normal process that the department has run through over the course of many, many years. And it is a fluid process and we really can't speculate and won't speculate on the final outcome other than to say, based on many years of past experience and several rounds of this and we have the benefit of sharing Thomas Parrot's experience at our Education Day, we do expect that common sense will prevail. In terms of the debt flows and the value proposition, we feel very good about the value proposition that our students achieve at our schools, the DeVry schools. Let me just give you an example of that. Just consider a graduate of Chamberlain College of Nursing who would pay somewhere around $68,000 in tuition and fees and leaves school with debt of about $34,000 on average. Now he or she would typically make about $55,000 a year and that's starting, obviously, it goes up from there because they have excellent lifelong career prospects and that's all enabled by the education that they received at Chamberlain. So we've done an ROI, we've returned an educational investment analysis of that and it comes out to about 28% return on educational investment over the 30-year career. That is a very strong value proposition. I don't know about you, but other than DeVry, I don't have anything in my portfolio so I expect that kind of a return. So students and parents understand that and that's really what supports the value proposition across other schools.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'm sorry, we don't have fresh data, but I can comment on, we like to say, career statistics, to our graduate career statistics. And the job market is tough. We are continuing to invest in that area, I. mentioned 150 career services advisors, one of t
componenttext: No, I'm sorry, we don't have fresh data, but I can comment on, we like to say, career statistics, to our graduate career statistics. And the job market is tough. We are continuing to invest in that area, I. mentioned 150 career services advisors, one of the largest career services offices of any university that you can find. And we're going to add even more on top of that, but we don't have an update. The next update on the statistics will be on our next conference call, which should be in April. And then again, in August when we report year end. And this is a good opportunity, Mark, I'm glad you raised this because I'd like to give everyone a heads up that from that point forward, we're going to be reporting statistics on an annual basis. And the reason is the statistics won't really change dramatically from period to period, but we spend a lot of staff time going through all of that, getting ready for that reporting. So it's not really worth it. So it's an increase to staff productivity and reduces the amount of collateral materials that are produced from each locations that are three times a year to one time a year. So you'll still get an update, and you look for an update in April, look for another one in August, and then it will be annual in August from thereafter.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and just to be clear that collateral material is really within DeVry University with a need to the school locations provided that, so it's really from a school perspective, trying to make life simpler and easier for them.
componenttext: Yes, and just to be clear that collateral material is really within DeVry University with a need to the school locations provided that, so it's really from a school perspective, trying to make life simpler and easier for them.

componenttextpreview: Oh, that's our fees. We changed the structure of our revenue. And when we did our switch in price in a year ago, we do some of our, I call them, nuisance fees, and so that's why that's going down. And also, some of the Becker materials are in that line as
componenttext: Oh, that's our fees. We changed the structure of our revenue. And when we did our switch in price in a year ago, we do some of our, I call them, nuisance fees, and so that's why that's going down. And also, some of the Becker materials are in that line as well. And obviously, Becker is down.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: I think the domino effect there is the shift from tuition to fee.

componenttext: Yes. I'm sorry, so I think you thought [ph] like the segment numbers.

componenttext: So for modeling purposes going forward, we should be kind of looking at this new, I guess, other add as a percentage of net revenue as a guidepost going forward?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus on the Business Management and Technology area. There was a report released last week by the Higher Education Research Institute, where they're seeing a slowdown in the number of freshmen that are choosing to go into business. Now I know
componenttext: I wanted to focus on the Business Management and Technology area. There was a report released last week by the Higher Education Research Institute, where they're seeing a slowdown in the number of freshmen that are choosing to go into business. Now I know that they focused mostly on traditional schools. But I'm just wondering, are you seeing any of that in any of your undergrad classes or your graduate classes?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No, Sir, Jeff, we're not. We're seeing a strong interest in business programs. And I'm seeing it at the bachelor's and the master's degree level. I'm not sure if there's any other color I can give on that. I mean, we're not seeing that at all.
componenttext: No, Sir, Jeff, we're not. We're seeing a strong interest in business programs. And I'm seeing it at the bachelor's and the master's degree level. I'm not sure if there's any other color I can give on that. I mean, we're not seeing that at all.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010

componenttext: Just to shift gears, just focus on another regulatory issue, and this will be cohort default rate. I know next month you'll be getting your cohort default rates for fiscal year '08 but you probably have some indication how those are turning out. I'm just wondering if you can comment on that.
