componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I know that, that's always been the tradition, that's always been. And we think that's the right thing, that numbers should be reported when they're numbers, when they're final. And in recent times, for various reasons, maybe that tradition, some
componenttext: Yes. So I know that, that's always been the tradition, that's always been. And we think that's the right thing, that numbers should be reported when they're numbers, when they're final. And in recent times, for various reasons, maybe that tradition, some people departed from that tradition. But I think you're going to see people get back to that tradition, unless there are some specific reason or some organizationally specific reason why somebody feels compelled to do that. You should expect to see all the schools support that when they're final numbers.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And just one quick numbers question, I guess for Rick. I know the tax rate has been moving up because you've seen more of a shift towards your domestic income. Should we be seeing that continuing over the next few quarters? Or have you kind of anniversari
componenttext: And just one quick numbers question, I guess for Rick. I know the tax rate has been moving up because you've seen more of a shift towards your domestic income. Should we be seeing that continuing over the next few quarters? Or have you kind of anniversaried the major aspects of that shift?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the rate that we have implicit in our year-to-date results of just under 33%, it should be a good barometer what it should for the full fiscal year at this point. That's how we try and estimate it. And then as we go forward, it's just again how big
componenttext: Well, the rate that we have implicit in our year-to-date results of just under 33%, it should be a good barometer what it should for the full fiscal year at this point. That's how we try and estimate it. And then as we go forward, it's just again how big of a growth factor do we see in the profits in the Business, Technology and Management segments, and within Professional Education and within the domestic pieces of Medical and Healthcare, relative to Ross University. And so if that shifts more domestic that would continue to inch that tax rate up a little bit over time.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And ladies and gentlemen, your next question will be from the line of Jerry Herman with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, your next question will be from the line of Jerry Herman with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: First question is actually about Neg Reg, but actually, the other team, the foreign medical schools' team. Is there anything that came out of that language or out of those professions that you think will affect your business in any way or the competition?
componenttext: First question is actually about Neg Reg, but actually, the other team, the foreign medical schools' team. Is there anything that came out of that language or out of those professions that you think will affect your business in any way or the competition? And then maybe just as part of that, is there anything changing or different on the competitive landscape for Ross?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of the negotiated rule-making sessions there, and again, we were honored to have Dr. Nancy Perry as one of the team members. When it's in flux, there's nothing to really comment on, so we won't. And in terms of increased competition, no, we
componenttext: Yes. In terms of the negotiated rule-making sessions there, and again, we were honored to have Dr. Nancy Perry as one of the team members. When it's in flux, there's nothing to really comment on, so we won't. And in terms of increased competition, no, we really haven't seen significant levels of new competition. Ross University School of Medicine is now providing more new physicians to the United States residency system than any other school. And by the way, this past year, we vaulted to the number one ranking for African-American physician, number three ranking for Hispanic-American physician, number one ranking for Primary Care physician. So clearly, there's a need and we're hoping to fulfill that need. But the level of competition -- certainly, there are plenty of competition but I don't see material change in that competitive dynamic.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then one for Rick. It's about margins, Rick. Usually, your third quarter margins are a bit higher than your second quarter margins. The second quarter margins were pretty high but I guess there's also some influences on the business, i.e, Fanor and so
componenttext: And then one for Rick. It's about margins, Rick. Usually, your third quarter margins are a bit higher than your second quarter margins. The second quarter margins were pretty high but I guess there's also some influences on the business, i.e, Fanor and some others. Is it fair to assume that, sequentially, margins will be better in the third versus the second?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I characterized that usually, the first and fourth quarter margins are little bit lower than the second and the third. So my expectation would be that our margins in the third quarter shouldn't be that dissimilar from what we've had this quarter,
componenttext: I guess I characterized that usually, the first and fourth quarter margins are little bit lower than the second and the third. So my expectation would be that our margins in the third quarter shouldn't be that dissimilar from what we've had this quarter, then they should go down in the fourth quarter.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is about persistence. DVU's persistence in particular was up quite a bit. Could you talk about the sustainability of persistence and opportunity for increasing persistence?
componenttext: My question is about persistence. DVU's persistence in particular was up quite a bit. Could you talk about the sustainability of persistence and opportunity for increasing persistence?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are very focused on that across all our schools, including DeVry University that you mentioned. And there are things that we do inside the classroom, and there are things we do outside the classroom. And you can have the greatest curriculum in the
componenttext: Yes. We are very focused on that across all our schools, including DeVry University that you mentioned. And there are things that we do inside the classroom, and there are things we do outside the classroom. And you can have the greatest curriculum in the world and the greatest professors in the world. And we certainly think very highly of our curriculum and of our professors. But if you have that, you don't have the supporting student services to surround the classroom and support the student then especially with working adults students or other non-traditional students in the same deposit. You need both in order to support those students and help them to succeed, and persist and graduate. And that's why we are investing in areas like Student Central, which provides the kinds of support services in a very clear, easy-to-access kind of format for our students, and many other sort of curriculum changes and academic changes as well to keep that focus. So when we talk about investments, this is one of the most important areas that we're constantly looking for ideas from our professors and from our service people. Give us ideas, give us projects, so we can pile the capacity to invest in. Those are the highest-return projects that we can invest in. So those are the kinds of things that we're doing to keep working on persistence.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, could you talk about some of that quantitatively? I'm asking, persistence was up significantly year-over-year in DVU. I'm asking is there anything unusual about the elevation? Do you think you can continue to improve on this? Will DVU's persistenc
componenttext: Daniel, could you talk about some of that quantitatively? I'm asking, persistence was up significantly year-over-year in DVU. I'm asking is there anything unusual about the elevation? Do you think you can continue to improve on this? Will DVU's persistence continue to rise sort of near term and intermediate term?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: That's certainly our goal, is that the persistence can continue to rise. But I don't have specific numbers to give you, Andrew. But yes, that is our goal that persistence can and that is our goal that it will continue to rise.
componenttext: That's certainly our goal, is that the persistence can continue to rise. But I don't have specific numbers to give you, Andrew. But yes, that is our goal that persistence can and that is our goal that it will continue to rise.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think labor markets when they improve will be a headwind to persistence?
componenttext: And do you think labor markets when they improve will be a headwind to persistence?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It could be. But I don't think that so much so that we won't be able to continue to grow the enrollments at our universities. And that's why I sort of provided that example. And it's just the example that I have from a very strong period of the 90s. Even
componenttext: It could be. But I don't think that so much so that we won't be able to continue to grow the enrollments at our universities. And that's why I sort of provided that example. And it's just the example that I have from a very strong period of the 90s. Even though the unemployment rate went down, the economy got stronger, we were still able to continue to grow our enrollments.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're pretty confident on the direction of persistence.
componenttext: It sounds like you're pretty confident on the direction of persistence.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Ariel Sokol with Wedbush.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Ariel Sokol with Wedbush.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So a question regarding acquisitions, you paid down debt in the quarter. And it looks like you're almost done with the last one, so a couple of questions. One, what does the pipeline look regarding future acquisitions and how may it have changed over the
componenttext: So a question regarding acquisitions, you paid down debt in the quarter. And it looks like you're almost done with the last one, so a couple of questions. One, what does the pipeline look regarding future acquisitions and how may it have changed over the past couple of months? And two, is the regulatory environment and perhaps gainful employment a variable for either you as the buyer or alternatively, is it a variable for potential sellers that you're having conversations with?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We're certainly, looking at acquisitions all the time. And we feel that we built over the last couple of years a very, very strong function there of internal resources and external resources to assess potential mergers, acquisitions, to do very, very thor
componenttext: We're certainly, looking at acquisitions all the time. And we feel that we built over the last couple of years a very, very strong function there of internal resources and external resources to assess potential mergers, acquisitions, to do very, very thorough due diligence and then to apply very focused acquisition integration once the school becomes part of the DeVry family. And so we feel very good about those resources and our track record in this regard, and we continue to look for acquisitions in the future. One of the things that I've commented on recently in Education Day was over the last couple of years, we are sort of building the framework for the house. And now we've largely built that and the focus is shifting a little bit more to kind of filling in the framework that we built. So those are the kinds of acquisitions that we might see to continue filling out at the international framework, continue filling out at the pre-baccalaureate level and those kinds of things. In terms of an impact from the current discussions that are going on in negotiated rule-making process, I can't say that I've seen them have a significant impact one way or the other in our review of potential acquisitions.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Trace Urdan with Signal Hill.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Trace Urdan with Signal Hill.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, you used the Chamberlain example and I'm returning to this because you kind of open the door here. But you used the Chamberlain example, which is a terrific example and comes in well underneath this 8% threshold that the department is talking abou
componenttext: Daniel, you used the Chamberlain example and I'm returning to this because you kind of open the door here. But you used the Chamberlain example, which is a terrific example and comes in well underneath this 8% threshold that the department is talking about. But normally, what you talked to us about is the $45,000 that is earned by DeVry graduates, which would fail to meet that threshold. So I'm wondering what you do with that example or how you think about that? Or do you think, when you make that statement that you think common sense will prevail, is it your feeling that the criterion here will move to accommodate schools like DeVry?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Essentially, yes. We think common sense will prevail and DeVry University founded in 1931, approaching its 80th anniversary, I don't think it's going to suddenly go out of business in its 81st year or whatever. I don't think that there's going to be a pro
componenttext: Essentially, yes. We think common sense will prevail and DeVry University founded in 1931, approaching its 80th anniversary, I don't think it's going to suddenly go out of business in its 81st year or whatever. I don't think that there's going to be a problem.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you share with us maybe what the lifetime cohort default rate looks like for DeVry?
componenttext: Could you share with us maybe what the lifetime cohort default rate looks like for DeVry?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Lifetime, no, we don't have figures like that to share.
componenttext: Lifetime, no, we don't have figures like that to share.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you know off hand what, including deferments in the cohort default rate does to the numbers maybe without being specific but just order of magnitude?
componenttext: Do you know off hand what, including deferments in the cohort default rate does to the numbers maybe without being specific but just order of magnitude?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think we've given information recently in the last couple of months that some people have seen that. And there's an increase, certainly, when you go from two years to three years. But none of our institutions does that, trip any wires or crea
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think we've given information recently in the last couple of months that some people have seen that. And there's an increase, certainly, when you go from two years to three years. But none of our institutions does that, trip any wires or create a major problem. It's something that we're concerned about. It's something that we are actively working with students, with lenders to ensure that we educate students and parents on their responsibilities. These are the kinds of activities that have proven over time to help improve the performance and repaying those, the financial obligations and thereby reducing default rate and so we continue to manage that. But I want to be very clear to everybody that there's nothing in any sort of rumors that sort of trip the wire or anything like that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So I mean, not to press this point too much but looking at those three-year numbers, which have not had the benefit of being "managed," do you think like those three-year numbers kind of give you a pretty good proxy for what those defaults look like when
componenttext: So I mean, not to press this point too much but looking at those three-year numbers, which have not had the benefit of being "managed," do you think like those three-year numbers kind of give you a pretty good proxy for what those defaults look like when deferments are not included in the calculation, is that fair?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know. And I really just can't comment on that one, Trace, sorry.
componenttext: I don't know. And I really just can't comment on that one, Trace, sorry.

componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The question about income-based repayment, I know CDR is not really an issue for you. But have you looked at income-based repayment? Can that help you get your cohort default rates even lower? And if you haven't looked at it, do you think it's significant
componenttext: The question about income-based repayment, I know CDR is not really an issue for you. But have you looked at income-based repayment? Can that help you get your cohort default rates even lower? And if you haven't looked at it, do you think it's significant for some of your students? And can you size it all?

componenttext: Yes, we support that. We think it's a good idea. And we support all kinds of creative ideas like that that can help students be helpful to students. And yes, I think that would probably be a positive.

componenttext: Any way to size the percentage of your students that could avoid defaults through an income-based repayment program?

componenttext: Not off the top of my head. Sorry, Paul, I just don't have a number to give you off the top of my head.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And next you have question from the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.
componenttext: And next you have question from the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with the question that probably would have been the first one out of the queue, if it's four, five years ago, which is just how enrollments went in the fall start for the younger high school population versus the working adult students?
componenttext: I wanted to start with the question that probably would have been the first one out of the queue, if it's four, five years ago, which is just how enrollments went in the fall start for the younger high school population versus the working adult students?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of our high school-- I got to thank you for that question. Thank you for bring us back to just talking about students and education. It is refreshing. I would say that, as an overarching point on that, Corey, we do feel very good about -- we like
componenttext: In terms of our high school-- I got to thank you for that question. Thank you for bring us back to just talking about students and education. It is refreshing. I would say that, as an overarching point on that, Corey, we do feel very good about -- we like the Traditional Out of High School Traditional College-Age Students segment, and we like the Working Adult segment. And we really like the fact that our strategy encompasses offerings and services to both of those overall segments of students. And we find a lot of synergy and a lot of benefit in having programs that respond to the needs of both those segments, not just one or the other. We are actually investing and focusing even more of the weight on the High School segment and we expect to see synergies from our K-12 program at Advanced Academics, in fact, is helping that. And also, the fact that we run high school programs, high school recruiting programs, high school educational programs at not just DeVry University but also at Chamberlain College of Nursing and at Apollo College and Western Career College that really are additive to the whole. So we feel good about the high school program and I think we'll see continued improvements there. And Rick, do you want to add anything to the high school question?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, the only thing I would add is that when you look at our enrollment growth like we disclosed back in December, we've seen a nice balance in the growth rates between on-site and online. If you go back five years ago, you would have seen on-sit
componenttext: Yes. I guess, the only thing I would add is that when you look at our enrollment growth like we disclosed back in December, we've seen a nice balance in the growth rates between on-site and online. If you go back five years ago, you would have seen on-site actually experiencing some declines and online really driving some of the growth. Whereas now, given our best of both philosophy, we're seeing growth both in online and on-site in pretty equal proportions.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And is online still primarily a working adult model or is the younger traditional students interested in online as well now?
componenttext: And is online still primarily a working adult model or is the younger traditional students interested in online as well now?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's still primarily the working adult. But increasingly, the traditional college age student coming out of high school is taking online courses. So it's really a mix and match. And I think that's really the best of both, online and on-site, is where the
componenttext: It's still primarily the working adult. But increasingly, the traditional college age student coming out of high school is taking online courses. So it's really a mix and match. And I think that's really the best of both, online and on-site, is where the market's going. That's where the demand from students is going. And we've been saying that for over 10 years. That's why we've never separated the online and the on-site. We never give separate the numbers. We always talked about it in terms of total online course takers, and it's for that very reason. So that's the dynamic that we're seeing.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And I have one other question for Rick. You are helpful at the Education Day. You talked about long-term targets for each of the segments. And can you just put that in perspective? I mean, it's so obvious that you're well above those targets particularly
componenttext: And I have one other question for Rick. You are helpful at the Education Day. You talked about long-term targets for each of the segments. And can you just put that in perspective? I mean, it's so obvious that you're well above those targets particularly in the Business, Technology and Management segment. Will the goal be to meet those targets year in and year out? Or would you consider it a victory if the compound annual growth rate ends up being at those levels in some years, so you're below that rate compounded over this year, when you're going to move well above [ph] the rate?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd said that the success we're having this year, the strong results that have exceeded the goal in fiscal '10, I don't think would lead us to believe that we would then be below that for the next couple of years to average it out, if that's what
componenttext: I guess, I'd said that the success we're having this year, the strong results that have exceeded the goal in fiscal '10, I don't think would lead us to believe that we would then be below that for the next couple of years to average it out, if that's what you're asking. I think we feel good about being able to deliver roughly 20% earnings growth going forward after this year as the base.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we challenge ourselves to continue that, even though we've set a higher bar, you might say.
componenttext: Yes. So we challenge ourselves to continue that, even though we've set a higher bar, you might say.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a question now from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And you have a question now from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, there was a lot of talk of you had really nice margins, and there's talk about some branding and marketing spend that was delayed in the first quarter. And I think it's already been covered in the Q&A today that you're looking for comparable
componenttext: Last quarter, there was a lot of talk of you had really nice margins, and there's talk about some branding and marketing spend that was delayed in the first quarter. And I think it's already been covered in the Q&A today that you're looking for comparable margins, 3Q versus 2Q. But could we go down to the weeds a little bit and talk about some of the investments that you are making currently including marketing?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start and Daniel can add to it. But the investments, when  we talk investments, we're talking both spending that as expense and spending that to capitalize. I mean, the capital spend we've talked about, the Project Delta's a big piece of that
componenttext: Sure. Let me start and Daniel can add to it. But the investments, when  we talk investments, we're talking both spending that as expense and spending that to capitalize. I mean, the capital spend we've talked about, the Project Delta's a big piece of that along with the spending within DeVry University for makeovers and expansion and some real estate optimization activities, expansion at Chamberlain, expansion at U.S. Education. The types of things that hit expenses are in the areas of academic quality, branded quality and just growth initiatives. Academic quality would be things like our Student Central rollouts and support behind the Career Services advisors that Daniel mentioned, more student services to work with students throughout the time from they first enrolled to they graduate, our brand quality in terms of the things that Daniel mentioned on Keller awareness, and we launched initiatives at certain locations to really get some resurgence in locations that maybe need a little jumpstart, and then growth and adding more admissions advisors in online, for example. The more we grow, we need people that can work with the students and advise them upfront. So those are the types of things that we're investing in.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say, I mean, Daniel mentioned earlier that you've really been investing a lot in the past couple of years. And people would mention that you're not showing, perhaps, some of the margin expansion that others had seen and certainly putting tha
componenttext: Is it fair to say, I mean, Daniel mentioned earlier that you've really been investing a lot in the past couple of years. And people would mention that you're not showing, perhaps, some of the margin expansion that others had seen and certainly putting that up now. So is it a nice measured pace now? Or could there potentially be some lumpiness going forward?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're always going to take advantage of opportunities. We're not going to be shy from making investments in academic quality or other quality initiatives, where we think that it's warranted. And so could there be some lumpiness? Without a doubt. We'
componenttext: Well, we're always going to take advantage of opportunities. We're not going to be shy from making investments in academic quality or other quality initiatives, where we think that it's warranted. And so could there be some lumpiness? Without a doubt. We're not managing this for the quarter, we're managing this for the long term. But I think we've proven in field that as we invest and make these investments that they will pay out over the long term. And so when you look at it in a year-to-year basis, we think that, again, should be pretty consistent in terms of our 20% earnings growth on a compound annual basis.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You guys did a nice job of talking ahead of time about seasonality in the first half of the fiscal year with regard to the Other Educational Services segment. Anything to look out for in the second half there?
componenttext: You guys did a nice job of talking ahead of time about seasonality in the first half of the fiscal year with regard to the Other Educational Services segment. Anything to look out for in the second half there?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, if I recall, the third quarter is going to be pretty close to what we saw in the second quarter, the revenue continue to build. But in the fourth quarter, you do have -- I think June, where there's some weeks where we don't have classes, so you e
componenttext: I think, if I recall, the third quarter is going to be pretty close to what we saw in the second quarter, the revenue continue to build. But in the fourth quarter, you do have -- I think June, where there's some weeks where we don't have classes, so you end up having the revenue not be as large in the fourth quarter because of that. In Advanced Academics, for example, high school ending in early June.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a question now from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.
componenttext: And you have a question now from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, can you give us any sense, as we think about a huge margin expansion in the DeVry University segment, how much of that over the last few years has driven by mix shift and growth of your Online business? And secondly, how much of that has been dri
componenttext: I guess, can you give us any sense, as we think about a huge margin expansion in the DeVry University segment, how much of that over the last few years has driven by mix shift and growth of your Online business? And secondly, how much of that has been driven by this whole concept of the co-located schools? I think it's in your company expense, the paying some rent expense or other payment to that segment to use those facilities?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would give it a shot here. Rick certainly have more color. But I would say that the biggest driver's operating leverage. In terms of mix shift, I think that slowed down as a percentage over the last little while relative to what it's been a couple
componenttext: Well, I would give it a shot here. Rick certainly have more color. But I would say that the biggest driver's operating leverage. In terms of mix shift, I think that slowed down as a percentage over the last little while relative to what it's been a couple of years ago. Co-locations are a wonderful strategy. They're paying off in excess of our expectation. And so we continue to look for those opportunities. I just mentioned four Chamberlain co-locations here in a period of about a year. And we're also looking at Apollo College and Western Career College opportunities to co-locate with Chamberlain and with DeVry University. So all of those, I think, are good factors.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add that online has got good attractive incremental margins, it's by the nature of online. But on-site, given where we are today, as we, either through the co-locations utilizing the facility or through the strong enrollment results we'v
componenttext: Yes. I would just add that online has got good attractive incremental margins, it's by the nature of online. But on-site, given where we are today, as we, either through the co-locations utilizing the facility or through the strong enrollment results we've had, where you have students sit in empty chairs within a facility, brick and mortar that's already existing that leads to that strong incremental pull-through that we've been experiencing here short term. And we still have available capacity as we go forward. So for the not-too-distant future, we should continue to see good leverage.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you've laid out the long-term plans at your Investor Day, it seemed to include not only moderate pricing growth for the segment but also, clearly, the expectation of some moderate leverage as you grow. Can you give us any sense as to what the upp
componenttext: And when you've laid out the long-term plans at your Investor Day, it seemed to include not only moderate pricing growth for the segment but also, clearly, the expectation of some moderate leverage as you grow. Can you give us any sense as to what the upper bounds might be? Obviously, today, with the terrific growth, it seems like it's been pretty easy the last couple of years. But it's got to be getting somewhat tougher particularly if one expects enrollments to slow down maybe in fiscal '11 or '12, towards that long-term target. I guess, are you comfortable with all the leverage as you see them, that you can continue to get over the next several years listed [ph] on this fiscal year?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. I would say that it -- we've been working pretty hard over the last couple of years. And our people have worked incredibly hard. And really, these results are a testament to the teams' hard work. And if we continue to do that and keep the focu
componenttext: Sure, Gary. I would say that it -- we've been working pretty hard over the last couple of years. And our people have worked incredibly hard. And really, these results are a testament to the teams' hard work. And if we continue to do that and keep the focus on our students and academic success, we really don't see any reason that we can't continue to achieve the targets that we've laid out at Investor Day and at Education Day. And while there may be something that get a little bit harder, there are some other things that we haven't really even pulled the lever on. And the earlier question that Amy asked about Project Delta is an example of that. I mean, we're investing in this new system for a reason, better service and better productivity for our students. And we haven't rolled out yet, so we would expect that to be a lever. We're certainly gearing up and looking for other ways to be more efficient and more effective in many areas throughout the operations. So I think that, that's one of the nature of management, you're always finding, you pursued this particular initiative and that kind of maybe ran its course but it continues to pay off for you. And then you move on to the next one. And we see plenty of opportunities here to keep the good thing going.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you mentioned earlier you might do some more actual branding work with Keller. And I know that was something that got mentioned a couple of times at the Investor Day, a larger percent of your ad spend on branding. Can you give us a sense as to wha
componenttext: I think you mentioned earlier you might do some more actual branding work with Keller. And I know that was something that got mentioned a couple of times at the Investor Day, a larger percent of your ad spend on branding. Can you give us a sense as to what type of format are you talking television commercials like we've seen a couple of our competitors doing? Or how are you thinking about more time on branding?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jan-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. And we'd like to -- instead of using that word, we're trying to use the word identity. And so that's really what I was talking about. But yes, we're building the identity, building the awareness of Keller. One of the things I think we talked about b
componenttext: Sure. And we'd like to -- instead of using that word, we're trying to use the word identity. And so that's really what I was talking about. But yes, we're building the identity, building the awareness of Keller. One of the things I think we talked about back at the Education Day was down the undergraduates side. DeVry University has quite a high awareness, and we need to work on its consideration. Whereas Keller, specifically the Graduate School of DeVry University, has -- when you know about it, you have very high consideration. It's just none of the people know about, so we need to increase the awareness. So that's the strategy there. In terms of some of the tools that we'd use to increase that awareness and identity, we would use a very -- because we know not a lot of new inventions under the sun here. We've used the same sorts of identity-building activities that traditional universities you might see, billboards or television ads or online ad. Certainly, the social media, social marketing is a newer area. And we are very well versed in the opportunities there. So those are all the kinds of opportunities that we have. One opportunity we don't have that some of the traditionals have, a big-time sports team. We can't pull that lever real hard. But pretty much everything else, you'll see us doing.Listen, thanks everyone for your questions. And our next conference call, which is April 22, we will be reporting the third quarter financial results and the spring enrollment numbers. So we would like to thank everyone on this call for your continued support of DeVry. Thanks very much. Have a great afternoon.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fiscal 2010 Third Quarter Conference Call. My name is Jeremy and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to your host for
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fiscal 2010 Third Quarter Conference Call. My name is Jeremy and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Joan Bates, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may proceed.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy. And I'd like to welcome everyone to DeVry's Third Quarter Conference Call. With me today from DeVry senior leadership team are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Fina
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy. And I'd like to welcome everyone to DeVry's Third Quarter Conference Call. With me today from DeVry senior leadership team are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please be advised that statements made on this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements subject to the Safe Harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements generally can be identified by phrases such as DeVry, Inc. or its management has a view, objective or outlook, or that management believes, expects, anticipates, foresees, forecasts, estimates or other words or phrases of similar importance. Actual results may differ materially from those projected or implied. Potential risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause results to differ are described more fully in Item 1A, Risk Factors in the DeVry's most recent annual report on Form 10-K for the year ending June 30, 2009, and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on August 26, 2009. Telephone and webcast replays of the call are available until May 4, 2010. To access these replays, please refer to today's press release for information.
Daniel Hamburger will begin today's call with a quick overview followed by a review of the financial results by Rick Gunst. Daniel will then provide an operations update before opening up the call for your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Daniel.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Joan and thank you all for very much for joining us today. We're pleased to announce another quarter of strong performance, driven by the continued execution of our diversification strategy and by our operating philosophy. And namely, that i
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Joan and thank you all for very much for joining us today. We're pleased to announce another quarter of strong performance, driven by the continued execution of our diversification strategy and by our operating philosophy. And namely, that is that "Quality Leads to Growth". During the quarter, total undergraduate enrolment for DeVry University was up nearly 26% from the year-ago period, to a record of 66,909 students. These results flow directly from the investments we’ve made and the quality of our programs and services.
And we’re being careful stewards of our resources. An example of that is co-location. In today's press release, we highlighted two co-locations between DeVry University and Chamberlain College of Nursing in Crystal City, Virginia and in Chicago. These co-locations will further optimize utilization at those existing facilities and it’ll enhance academic student experience. 
Now if there was a theme this quarter, it would be healthcare. First of all, of course, we saw the passage of the new healthcare reform legislation. This law potentially means that 32 million more Americans will have health insurance by 2014.
This will put even more demand on an already strained system. Our schools are well positioned to educate the professionals who will be serving America's growing healthcare needs into the future. And Chamberlain College of Nursing is a great example of how we’ll help to meet this demand. Because even before this law was signed, it was forecasted that we would be 1 million nurses short by the end of this decade. And yet our nation's nursing schools are turning away almost 100,000 qualified applicants each and every year because there aren't enough seats to meet the demand. So Chamberlain is a great example of how DeVry and the private sector as a whole are meeting the capacity needs that we have. 
And likewise, in the world of medical education, it’s expected that we'll be 125,000 physicians short within 15 years. Ross University School of Medicine is helping to fulfill this critical need. And there's also a growing shortage of ancillary care and allied health professionals. And recently we made a change that we think paves the way to significantly meet the needs of these professionals as well because, during this quarter, we announced the name change of the two schools that make up U.S. Education: Western Career College and Apollo College. 
On July 1, the two will become Carrington College. It will be Carrington College California and Carrington College, respectively. And so taken together our medical and healthcare group is serving nearly 24,000 students and we’re a leading educator at all levels of healthcare, from the medical assistant to the nurse to the physician.
As millions of Americans become insured under healthcare reform, we expect to play an important role in meeting the need for healthcare professionals in this country. So with that brief introduction, let me turn the call over to Rick and we’ll go through the financial results.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon, everyone. We once again delivered strong revenue and earnings results this quarter, while making investments in academic quality. Our strong revenue growth continued to be a key source of operating leverage in improved
componenttext:
Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon, everyone. We once again delivered strong revenue and earnings results this quarter, while making investments in academic quality. Our strong revenue growth continued to be a key source of operating leverage in improved margins and profitably. 
Record quarterly revenue of $504 million was up about 29% versus prior year, with revenues still up 27%, excluding our acquisition of DeVry Brazil at April. Year-to-date revenue was up 32% and 26% when you exclude the impact of both DeVry Brazil and U.S. Education, which became part of DeVry in September of 2008.
Net income and earnings per share were both up about 60% in the quarter versus prior year on a reported basis, and up 51% after excluding a charge for a lease buyout from last year's results. Year-to-date earnings were up 63% on a reported basis and 59%, excluding last year's discrete item.
Pretax income margins for the first nine months was 22.1%, up 450 basis points versus the 17.6% margin achieved a year ago. We're obviously on our way to significantly surpass our historical full year peak margin of 17.1% this year and should exceed 20% by the end of the year as well. 
For your reference, third quarter results include expense related to share-based payments of approximately $2.2 million pretax or $1.8 million net of tax, a bit higher than last year. And our overall effective tax rate was 33.8% in the quarter and 33.3% year-to-date, up from our 30.4% rate for full fiscal year 2009, primarily due to the continued increase in domestic source income. 
Cost of Educational Services expense in the quarter increased by about 20% versus prior year, excluding last year's real estate charge and student service and administrative expense increased by 22%, both growing at double-digit rates, but less than revenue growth, with or without the acquisitions.
We continue to make prudent, targeted investments while still delivering leverage and efficiencies. With that let me now walk you through some of the key highlights of our operating segments, which are further detailed in our earnings release.
First, the Business, Technology, and Management segment continues to deliver very strong top and bottom line results. Revenue in the quarter was up about 29% versus prior year and 26% year-to-date, driven by the strong enrolment growth and increased retention, driven by our focus on student services. Segment operating income of $86 million in the quarter and $220 million year-to-date more than doubled versus prior year. The segment margin of 23.6% year-to-date was up about 900 basis points versus last year, reflecting the power of operating leverage on our cost base from the very strong top line growth.
Within the Medical and Healthcare segment, revenue was up 26% in the quarter driven by enrolment growth and pricing at Ross University and Chamberlain College of Nursing, along with good, but decelerating growth at U.S. Education. Third quarter operating income for the segment of $31 million was up about 19% versus last year. The margin was a bit lower than prior year driven by continued mix shift in the business mix within the segment with the growth of Chamberlain and U.S. Education, both which currently have lower margins than Ross University.
Also note that in Q4, we are planning increased spending associated with the start ups for Chamberlain in Chicago and Crystal City, Virginia as well as cost associated with the name change and geographic expansion within U.S. Education. 
Our Professional Education segment results continue to reflect the impact of the soft economy on the accounting and finance professions, with some slight signs of improvement. Revenue was up 1% in the quarter and down about 2% year-to-date versus last year. Operating income was down about 15% in the quarter and down 18% year-to-date. Once again, we don't expect performance to improve materially in calendar 2010, or really until the economic recovery takes hold and positively impacts hiring and training within these professions.
Lastly, our Other Educational Services segment contributed about $14 million of revenue in the quarter, but with an operating loss of $1.4 million. Advanced Academics had increased marketing spending in the quarter to drive future growth and our fiscal third quarter represents a seasonal low point for tuition revenue at DeVry Brazil. No classes were held for most of January, given the academic calendar in Brazil resulting in only about two months of revenue recognition in the quarter. This segment is expected to deliver operating income again in the fourth quarter.
Shifting to cash flow in the balance sheet. Cash flow from operations for the first nine months was $481 million versus $288 million last year driven by improved earnings and working capital. These strong cash flow results drove our cash and marketable securities balance to $502 million at the end of the third quarter, compared to $297 million last year. And our outstanding debt was $45 million, which is level with last quarter and down from $135 million last year.
Capital expenditures the first nine months was $102 million, about double the amount we spent last year. The spending has been focused on project Delta, which we believe will further enhance our ability to provide best-in-class service to our students, as well as on facility improvements within DeVry University and U.S. Education, and expansion within Ross University and Chamberlain College of Nursing. 
We also completed our home office move in January to two new locations here in the western suburbs of Chicago. We’re committed to investing in educational technology and capacity needed to serve our students and we've been successful in completing projects pending this year. Total capital spending is expected to be in the $130 million to $140 million range by the end of the year.
Our net accounts receivable balance continued to run lower than prior year despite our strong revenue growth. Net accounts receivable decreased to $156 million versus $180 million last year. Receivables per account within DeVry University were actually down compared to the balances last year as well as two years ago. 
Our year-to-date bad debt rate increased slightly versus last year to 3.1%, driven by the U.S. Ed. and DeVry Brazil additions. We have not experienced really any significant deterioration with bad debt in our legacy operations.
These results can be attributed to the impact of our financial aid processing system, focus on customer service and a tremendous effort of our campus and student finance teams. And I really do want to commend these people. When you factor in the tough economy to bring down receivables per account, let alone total receivables is a huge, huge achievement. 
Finally during the quarter, we began executing our third share repurchase program buying back about 100,000 shares at an average cost of $63.37 per share. So that concludes my comments and the strong results for the quarter and the first nine months of the year. Fiscal 2010 is going to be a breakthrough year for the organization, significantly surpassing our long-term financial goals given the power of operating leverage. The fourth quarter will continue to show margin improvement, albeit at a lower rate of growth than we achieved in the nine-month period. 
As we look ahead to fiscal 2011, we expect the Business, Technology and Management segment to continue to deliver strong revenue and earnings growth, driven by the flow-through of our recent strong enrolment growth and continued operating leverage. The Medical and Healthcare segment earnings, however, will likely be flat to maybe even slightly down next year. This is driven by capacity and enrolment constraints within Ross' Medical School that Daniel will discuss in a few minutes, along with startup costs associated with geographic expansion at Chamberlain and U.S. Education. 
In addition, we anticipate existing campus growth at U.S. Education to slow down as the economy recovers and unemployment levels decline. Finally, we hope to see improved top and bottom line results within Professional Education segment as the economy recovers and anticipate that the Other Educational Services segment will contribute more to revenue and earnings growth.
Overall, our diversification is serving us well as we expect to deliver results in line with our long-term financial goals for DeVry Inc. of double-digit revenue growth and roughly 20% earnings per share growth in fiscal 2011. With that, let me now turn the call back to Daniel for some color on the operating results.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Rick. Let me start with Business, Technology and Management segment, which, of course, is DeVry University and its Keller Graduate School of Management. This is another strong quarter of positive academic outcomes and excellent enrolment gro
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Rick. Let me start with Business, Technology and Management segment, which, of course, is DeVry University and its Keller Graduate School of Management. This is another strong quarter of positive academic outcomes and excellent enrolment growth. 
We were especially pleased to see contributions across all curriculum areas, degree levels and delivery modes. Let me give you some color on that. Total undergraduate enrolment in DeVry University’s Business programs grew 22%, Technology programs grew 27% and the Healthcare programs grew 46%.
We're also seeing significant enrolment growth at the graduate level as coursetakers rose 17% for the January session and more than 15% in March. 17% is the highest growth rate in total graduate coursetakers since 2003. We believe this demonstrates the strong return on the investments we're making to raise awareness of the quality of our graduate degree programs. 
The total number of online coursetakers at DeVry University the March session, this includes undergraduate and graduate together, increased 21.5% from the prior year and the campuses and centers grew nicely well. So we're seeing contributions to our overall strong growth rates at DeVry University from all channels, that’s curriculum areas, degree levels and delivery modes.
DeVry University continues to position itself as the career university and in line with this we've making investments in expanding career services for our students and hiring more career advisors. The most recent employment rate for DeVry University graduates in the active job market, who are employed within their field of study within six months of graduation, remained steady at 87.7%. And we believe this demonstrates that employers continue to see tremendous value in our graduates, despite the continued weakness in the job market. 
We also accelerated the rollout of our next generation student central location to better support our students from the time they enroll until they graduate. This innovative student central concept will be in all of our campuses by the end of fiscal 2010.
And DeVry University is continuing to invest in new location. Thus far in fiscal 2011, we expect to open new campuses near Houston and Phoenix as part of our plans to open five or six new locations in total at DeVry University next year. 
Now the key to DeVry University's strong performance is the quality of the learning experience we offer to our students. And the backbone of providing that quality is our highly-talented faculty. So I'm particularly proud of the talent we have teaching at DeVry University and wanted to highlight that beginning this month we'll be establishing a recurring faculty symposium. This will be another great arena for DeVry University’s thought leaders to learn from one another, presenting white papers and essential topics such as student retention, blended learning and many others.
Now I'd like to update you on Project Delta. As most of you know, this is a major student systems migration that will greatly improve productivity and student service at both DeVry University and at Chamberlain College of Nursing. Now as with any major systems project I've ever been involved in, we've experienced some delays and cost overruns. But as we’ve said many times, success means getting it right. And that's the most important thing. We will not launch any of the phases until they're fully tested and ready. Now we do expect initial phases to rollout in the coming months and we're excited about the capabilities Project Delta will provide to us and to our students.
Let me turn now to our Medical and Healthcare segment. At Ross University, we’ve continued to see growth as new student enrolment in January at the Med and Vet schools was up more than 14% and total student enrolment increased 8% from year ago. As those of you have been following us know, part of the growth strategy at Ross University School of Medicine is the development of a clinical education center located in Freeport, Grand Bahamas. One of the attractions of the clinical site, which opened in January of last year, was that it was expected to play a role in alleviating capacity constraints at Ross' main campus in Dominica. This hasn't gone according to plan. There's a few reasons for this. 
One reason has to do with student’s reaction to a funding difference. Title IV funding has not been available to students studying in Freeport. We knew this and so as a result, we developed an institutional loan alternative that alleviated any impact per student. But from a perception point of view, the fact that there was a difference, lead to a more cautious outlook on the part of existing students who were considering Freeport. 
And there was also a delay in the California review process. So just background on that. Four states, including California, require approval of international medical school programs in order to license graduates to participate in clinicals in their states. They also require notification for new locations. So Ross made the proper notification, but California later concluded that Freeport was subject to a more extensive evaluation process. Now we've heard nothing that would indicate that the California Medical Board has any concerns about the Freeport location or its academics or operations. It's just that it’s a process that you have to go through and we hope to receive formal approval by the end of the year.
And these things have combined to reduce the number of students in Freeport well below what we had been planning, which means that we need to add investment and resources in Dominica. So as we continue to work on the Freeport location, we're adding capacity in Dominica. We're adding additional classrooms, laboratory, space and faculty. We are committed to providing the resources our students need to receive a high-quality education. 
What all of this will mean is we're lowering new student enrolment for at least the upcoming May and September terms. And we’ll keep you informed of our progress on all these fronts as they unfold. In the meantime, we expect that our well-diversified portfolio of programs will enable DeVry overall to achieve its long-term performance goals. And to give you some perspective on that, we anticipate that the slowing of enrolment growth at Ross will affect earnings by approximately $5 million in fiscal 2011.
So we believe this is a prudent step and will allow Ross to manage through the near term and prepare for growth longer term. The situation reminds me of when we first acquired Ross and we made the conscious decision to slow enrolment growth for a time in order to improve outcomes for students. That investment laid the foundation for the excellent academic outcomes and the strong growth in applications that we've seen ever since. 
But here, although it's a different situation, we're making a similar investment for the short term that will allow us to better serve our existing student population and manage for long-term growth. 
So moving on within the segment, our Chamberlain College of Nursing continues to grow as enrolment was up 72% over the prior year. Chamberlain experienced strong growth at each of its campuses and across all of its programs. We continue to invest in geographic expansion at Chamberlain. 
For the two co-locations I mentioned earlier, we recently received approval from the Boards of Nursing in both Illinois and in Virginia. Both campuses received wonderful feedback from accreditor and nursing board review team.
Last week, I had the honor of keynoting the ribbon-cutting ceremony at the relocated campus in St. Louis, which is yet another co-location with DeVry University. As we toured this wonderful campus, it felt like we were in a hospital with nursing stations and ICU, patient simulators. And these simulators give our students the opportunity to learn in a life-like yet safe environment and provide an excellent academic experience. I discussed with the local government officials what a privilege it is to open a new 55,000 square-foot plus facility with state-of-the-art equipment at a time when public universities are capacity constrained. 
And then at Apollo College and Western Career College, soon-to-be Carrington Colleges, new enrolments dipped 2% while total enrollments were up 10% for the period. New enrollments were affected by several factors including a moderation in enrolment as the economy recovers, and a tougher comparison to last year's very strong growth, execution issues, which have been addressed, and near-term capacity constraints as we develop new locations. 
Later this year, U.S. Education is going to going to co-locate with DeVry University in Pomona, California. That'll be our first location in Southern California for what’s soon-to-be-called Carrington College of California.
Turning to our Professional Education segment. The economy continues to affect the accounting and finance fields that Becker Professional Education serves. But we're seeing early indications that the worst is over as our CPA segment is beginning to show modest growth. We believe Becker is well positioned for long-term growth. This is evident when you look at Accounting Today's list of the Top 100 Firms and see that Becker has relationships in place with 97 of them. 
Our Stalla Review for the CFA exam recently entered into partnerships with the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and with UBS to serve as their preferred partner. 
And then finally moving to our Other Educational Services segment. I’d like to comment on DeVry Brazil. Total enrollments were flat because of tougher comparisons in graduate student enrolment and the delay in the rollout of several new programs. 
Even though it's small today, we believe DeVry Brazil continues to have great potential for long-term growth. Right now, we're focused on building our infrastructure, including student services and online delivery, in order to build upon our quality offerings there and to foster future growth.
During the quarter, we received approvals for numerous new courses in the healthcare field in Brazil, including nursing, physiotherapy and nutrition and these should contribute positively to the future enrolment growth. We're also exploring further expansion options to the new locations. 
And I'd like to mention that we're building upon a strong foundation of academic quality at DeVry Brazil. For example, based on outcomes of the OAB exam, which is the equivalent of the bar exam in the U.S., for the second year in a row, Ruy Barbosa student test scores were number one in Salvador and number one among all private institutions in Brazil countrywide.
And so to wrap it up. Overall, we're very pleased with the results in the quarter. As more than anything they demonstrate that our diversification strategy is serving us well. While we discussed some near-term challenges at Ross University and a countercyclical moderation at U.S. Education, these are more than offset by the out-performance at DeVry University and at Chamberlain College of Nursing. 
So taken together, we're very well positioned to meet our near term and our long-term goals. So with that, we'd be happy to take questions. Joan?

componenttext: More of a conceptual question, but within the Business, Technology and Management segment, I'm wondering how you think about the potential for continued margin expansion over time? You're obviously going to have phenomenal expansion this year. And I'm wondering what kind of magnitude you're expecting over the next several years?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, not to the same magnitude we’ve had this year, I can tell you that much. But we do anticipate with the enrolment growth we've seen lately that, that will carry forward into next year and then the year after. We continue to give us good double-digi
componenttext: Well, not to the same magnitude we’ve had this year, I can tell you that much. But we do anticipate with the enrolment growth we've seen lately that, that will carry forward into next year and then the year after. We continue to give us good double-digit revenue growth and then as we go forward, it's going to be more focused on continued efficiencies to enable us to continue to drive overall operating margin improvement. I think it will come more from SS&A in the future than from cost of instruction as we continue to invest in academic quality.

componenttextpreview: I didn't say anything about top line. What I said about bottom line is for earnings for the segment. It’ll likely be relatively flat, maybe even slightly down. For the reasons in terms of the enrolment on Ross University that Daniel mentioned, along wit
componenttext: I didn't say anything about top line. What I said about bottom line is for earnings for the segment. It’ll likely be relatively flat, maybe even slightly down. For the reasons in terms of the enrolment on Ross University that Daniel mentioned, along with the start-up underwriting for the new locations and some of the name change costs in U.S. Education, and more expansion in U.S. Education and Chamberlain later in the year.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We have graduation rates of 31% at DeVry University, 30% at Chamberlain College [inaudible] and 67% at U.S. Education. And you have to bear in mind that that's the way they’re reported on a first-time, full-time basis. So that doesn't include all
componenttext: Sure. We have graduation rates of 31% at DeVry University, 30% at Chamberlain College [inaudible] and 67% at U.S. Education. And you have to bear in mind that that's the way they’re reported on a first-time, full-time basis. So that doesn't include all the other students who come in with transfer credits, which is at this point probably the majority of many of our students, anyway. And so I always urge caution in interpreting those. And also, we need to compare those to institutions who serve similar populations of students, often with several of the Department of Education's defined risk factors and other factors like that. So those are the numbers that we have.

componenttext: I can tell you they're definitely amenable to dialogue and I really commend the Department of Education for conducting a process of being very open, of listening. And I can tell you with first-hand experience and just in general, that they are listening and there's a lot of dialogue going on.

componenttext: Daniel, in your remarks about U.S. Education, you alluded to some execution issues. I was wondering if we could get a little color on that?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. What we saw was a little bit of turnover in the marketing department and that led to some fumbling, as well as in the Department of Enrolment Management, also. So just executional issues that happen from time to time. We had a bit of a stumble there.
componenttext: Yes. What we saw was a little bit of turnover in the marketing department and that led to some fumbling, as well as in the Department of Enrolment Management, also. So just executional issues that happen from time to time. We had a bit of a stumble there. And we've addressed that. We feel pretty confident we’ve addressed that. And it’s just part of the ongoing day-to-day, month-to-month type of management that you do. And so we think we've addressed that and that's what I was referring to.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And is that the first time this has occurred since you bought this company?
componenttext: And is that the first time this has occurred since you bought this company?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that was the most significant occurrence of something like that. And we have a really strong management team at U.S. Education, soon-to-be Carrington Colleges. And they very quickly addressed that. Unfortunately, not in time to make as much of
componenttext: I would say that was the most significant occurrence of something like that. And we have a really strong management team at U.S. Education, soon-to-be Carrington Colleges. And they very quickly addressed that. Unfortunately, not in time to make as much of an impact on that particular period that we saw. And that was only one factor in combination with the comparables and other factors that I mentioned. But I'm very confident that the strong management team that -- I’ll just start saying Carrington Colleges, I’ll jump the gun on July 1, at Carrington Colleges, I just kind of love the name so much. I am very confident in that management team and we continue to strengthen the management team. As you see in the press release, a new member of the team and we feel very good about how we run things there, very, very strong operating. But even with that, blips can occur from time to time and that's what we saw there.

componenttext: And just a quick follow-up, just on Ross. You mentioned the issues with the Freeport location and the California Medical Board. Are there any other issues with any other states? Did you see non-California students affected by this?
