headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, when you two called out countercyclicality for U.S. Ed, I know you also said it was other factors as well. I kind of think maybe it’s still early in the unemployment rate to start to crawl to countercyclicality. How would you judge the countercy
componenttext: Daniel, when you two called out countercyclicality for U.S. Ed, I know you also said it was other factors as well. I kind of think maybe it’s still early in the unemployment rate to start to crawl to countercyclicality. How would you judge the countercyclicality has affecting U.S. Ed? And do you see countercyclicality becoming a headwind for any other unit at DeVry?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's really U.S. Education or soon-to-be Carrington Colleges that's the most countercyclical within our family here at DeVry. And this is as we've said many times, that that's really balances out some of the other parts of our family where we're pro-c
componenttext: No, it's really U.S. Education or soon-to-be Carrington Colleges that's the most countercyclical within our family here at DeVry. And this is as we've said many times, that that's really balances out some of the other parts of our family where we're pro-cyclical, like Becker, or areas where we're really non-cyclical, like the medical school, nursing school, veterinary school. So from an overall DeVry perspective we can continue to -- and the most important thing is we can continue to achieve our goals, even if there is a little bit of, and I wouldn't call it a headwind as much as just a less of the tailwind that we've been seeing at the shorter term programs that we have at Carrington Colleges.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And could you also give a comment about student persistence rates going forward. What would be the drivers there?
componenttext: And could you also give a comment about student persistence rates going forward. What would be the drivers there?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, student persistence and retention is a huge focus for us from an academic perspective at all of our colleges and universities. And the drivers there would be things like this innovative student central model that we have put in place at DeVry Univer
componenttext: Well, student persistence and retention is a huge focus for us from an academic perspective at all of our colleges and universities. And the drivers there would be things like this innovative student central model that we have put in place at DeVry University and are rolling out to full rollout to provide the kind of student support services, academic advising, student services, part-time jobs, career services, financial aid services to support our students. That's what our students and graduates tell us helps to make a difference in helping them to persist and to graduate. It's providing that kind of support service that unfortunately, aren’t always provided at some of the public institutions. And that would be, I’d say, the number one area that is going to help us with persistence, along with the other investments that we pointed to in terms of just academics within the classroom, investments that we’re making to support our faculty. I’d point to all those factors.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think student persistence will be up because of those factors? Or will it be challenged because of any countercyclical effects?
componenttext: And do you think student persistence will be up because of those factors? Or will it be challenged because of any countercyclical effects?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, no. We think we can continue to make -- we've had improvements in student persistence and we've been doing that through the economic cycles. We'll continue to focus on that through the economic cycles as well.
componenttext: Oh, no. We think we can continue to make -- we've had improvements in student persistence and we've been doing that through the economic cycles. We'll continue to focus on that through the economic cycles as well.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will come from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.
componenttext: And your next question will come from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I realize Business, Technology segment is a key profit driver in the near term so this might seem like nitpicking, but I look at the press release and you've got either slightly negative growth or issues at three of the school groups between Ross and U.S.
componenttext: I realize Business, Technology segment is a key profit driver in the near term so this might seem like nitpicking, but I look at the press release and you've got either slightly negative growth or issues at three of the school groups between Ross and U.S. Ed. and slightly negative starts in Brazil. And I can't help but wonder maybe you've overextended yourself in terms of all the things you're trying to do here and successfully execute. I guess is this just sort of bad luck all around? Or what's your take on that thought?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Our take is that we're really pleased with the performance of the DeVry family this quarter. And we see tremendous opportunity to continue this strong growth in the near term and in the long-term. And we think that the strength, one of the strengths of De
componenttext: Our take is that we're really pleased with the performance of the DeVry family this quarter. And we see tremendous opportunity to continue this strong growth in the near term and in the long-term. And we think that the strength, one of the strengths of DeVry is our diversified positioning. And the things that you pointed to, you could talk -- I really would talk about each one on their own. I mean Brazil is a very, very small. That's a long-term investment that we're making. U.S. Education, I think we are going to see, as we've been saying -- I think anybody who says otherwise might not be looking at reality. Reality is, the tailwind of countercyclicality is not going to last forever. And that's okay, we can still continue to grow at U.S. Education or soon-to-be Carrington Colleges, as we invest in new locations in online and new programs as well. So even with the flagging of the tailwind, we are looking for and expecting growth at Carrington Colleges. So we can talk about each particular instance here, but overall when taken as a whole, I think what’s most important, we really like the array of colleges and universities that we have and we like our diversified positioning.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I've always thought of DeVry University, and I think you made this point a bunch of times, as much less countercyclical than a lot of the heavy diploma and maybe more associate-type businesses that are out there. But clearly the business has had a signifi
componenttext: I've always thought of DeVry University, and I think you made this point a bunch of times, as much less countercyclical than a lot of the heavy diploma and maybe more associate-type businesses that are out there. But clearly the business has had a significant acceleration in the last two fiscal years in terms of new student growth. Can you help me just get comfortable as I look at that trend? Understanding maybe how much of that or what has been -- you guys executing better versus just an improvement from the cycle? And is it reasonable to think that while it probably slows that this can remain at low double-digits or high-single to low double-digit grower as we look out over the next two to three years even in a stronger economy?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's really interesting, Gary, that DeVry University has been able to grow through good times and bad times. In fact, back in the vaunted '90s and the 20 plus percent earnings growth for 10 years in a row, 40 quarters, the average enrolment growth wa
componenttext: Yes. It's really interesting, Gary, that DeVry University has been able to grow through good times and bad times. In fact, back in the vaunted '90s and the 20 plus percent earnings growth for 10 years in a row, 40 quarters, the average enrolment growth was less than 10%. It was about 7%, 7.5%. And I think we shared last time that if you look at DeVry University's total enrollment growth, after the last recession we showed very good growth throughout and as that ended and we had falling unemployment. In an improving economy, DeVry University performed very, very well. So DeVry University's programs are really a lot less countercyclical than I think some people think. And when you think about that it makes sense because you got business programs, you've got technology programs and you’ve got an increasing cadre of health and healthcare technology programs at DeVry University. So there are programs that appeal to students across economic cycles. The other thing is DeVry University has a nice complement of both working adult students, like many others have, but also a lot of traditional college-age students coming directly from high school. And they don't stop making 18-year-olds in good or bad economic cycles, right? And so you have a nice stable base of 18-year-olds coming through. And that's a differentiator for DeVry University relative to many others as well. So we feel very confident in DeVry University's have ability to grow and serve students throughout good and bad economic cycles.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to think -- I mean I know you’ve talked over time of all the things you've done to run the business more efficiently. Is it fair to think that part of this acceleration has been sort of some of the internal processes and marketing better and
componenttext: Is it fair to think -- I mean I know you’ve talked over time of all the things you've done to run the business more efficiently. Is it fair to think that part of this acceleration has been sort of some of the internal processes and marketing better and what not that you've done? And some of that, is certainly -- would then be sustainable? Is that a fair concept?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes and maybe just try not to tout that too much. But to be fair, when we had our big downturn in the early part of this decade, first we pointed to our internal execution. We didn’t blame the market. Although there was a factor, that was the secon
componenttext: Yes. Yes and maybe just try not to tout that too much. But to be fair, when we had our big downturn in the early part of this decade, first we pointed to our internal execution. We didn’t blame the market. Although there was a factor, that was the secondary factor. And likewise, as we’ve gone through the turn around and continued to perform, yes, I would say the first factor is internal performance and the second factor is the market.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Amy Junker with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Amy Junker with Robert W. Baird.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, with respect to Project Delta, you mentioned you saw some delays. But I just want to clarify you haven't seen any disruption at this point, is that correct?
componenttext: Daniel, with respect to Project Delta, you mentioned you saw some delays. But I just want to clarify you haven't seen any disruption at this point, is that correct?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: That is absolutely correct. We have not seen any disruption. And really, we haven't rolled out very much at this point either. But that's the point is -- and why we're a little bit behind the original schedule and I reported that is actually, to underline
componenttext: That is absolutely correct. We have not seen any disruption. And really, we haven't rolled out very much at this point either. But that's the point is -- and why we're a little bit behind the original schedule and I reported that is actually, to underline the point I think you're getting to, which is sell no wine before its time. We will not roll out any module into the system until it's fully tested and ready. And that we've done the change management, which is something we teach at DeVry University and Keller Graduate School of Management, which is sort of academic term for training and making sure that everyone knows how to use the system properly. And so we're putting a big investment -- we’ve increased the investment in training and change management, which again kind of speaks to a little bit -- we’re a little bit over time, a little bit over budget. But I can tell you sometimes the wind isn't coming in under budget and under time. It's coming in a little over budget and a little bit over time, like you didn't blow anything up in the process. And from my experience, I can tell you that sometimes that is the definition of success with these larger systems projects and business change projects. So that's how we're approaching it. At the same time, I can tell you that over the last few months, I've seen the demos. I participated in some of the training and I've been blown away by the opportunity here, the opportunity for enhanced service to our students as well as internal productivity. But also, through that change management and training we’ve seen a level of excitement and enthusiasm from people that I've rarely seen in the many systems projects that I've been involved with both as a client and as consultant when I used to be with Accenture. Usually, it’s: oh gosh, when do we have to do this thing. This has been: wow, we can't wait, we can’t wait for the new system. So very confident that Project Delta is going to pay off and achieve the kind of returns that we're looking for.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones on Ross. You had commented that you're going to see slowing starts. And I just wanted to clarify should we expect an actual decline in starts? And could that lead to a decline in overall enrolments? Or you think this is more ju
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones on Ross. You had commented that you're going to see slowing starts. And I just wanted to clarify should we expect an actual decline in starts? And could that lead to a decline in overall enrolments? Or you think this is more just a slowing that's going to occur?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. You've got it. We do think that the new student enrolment will decline in May and September and that could be in a range of 30% to 40% even. We don't think that total student enrolment will decline. We think it will be about flat.
componenttext: Yes. You've got it. We do think that the new student enrolment will decline in May and September and that could be in a range of 30% to 40% even. We don't think that total student enrolment will decline. We think it will be about flat.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Rick, you had said that you thought the impact of that in 2011 would be about $5 million to the bottom line. And I just wanted to clarify, given those comments, can we still expect or do you still expect to be able to achieve your targeted 20% ne
componenttext: And then Rick, you had said that you thought the impact of that in 2011 would be about $5 million to the bottom line. And I just wanted to clarify, given those comments, can we still expect or do you still expect to be able to achieve your targeted 20% net income growth in that year on top of this phenomenal year you're having in 2010?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's still what we’re targeting. As Daniel said all along, that's the power of the diversification. Because we're doing this because of -- we need to manage through this with Ross. And we’re making these investments in expansion and Chamberlain
componenttext: Yes, that's still what we’re targeting. As Daniel said all along, that's the power of the diversification. Because we're doing this because of -- we need to manage through this with Ross. And we’re making these investments in expansion and Chamberlain and U.S. Education, soon-to-be Carrington College. And we can do that given the power of diversification and still come in, again, roughly 20%. We’re working through the details of our plans sort of as we speak, but we still think that's very much doable.

componenttext: Yes. I think the color commentary here would just be that as you look at the rate of new unemployment claims, for example, it's all starting to slow down, which is good for our country, good for our economy, right. We all want to see that. And that aspect of it, which does impact our non-degree programs in particular at Carrington, so the certificate programs a little bit more, we're starting to see a little bit of that. More into the kind of front end of interest, not so much necessarily in terms of the conversion from there. And the other thing that I would say is we're positioning Carrington increasingly for growth through new locations, new programs and online as I mentioned. But also the fact that we have a very healthy complement of degree programs, including nursing at Carrington and those are much less countercyclical. So we like the positioning.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add that we've been saying all along that since U.S. Education became part of DeVry 18 months ago, we've been the benefactor of the soft economy and the increase in inquiries as a result of the higher levels of unemployment. And now I think w
componenttext: I would just add that we've been saying all along that since U.S. Education became part of DeVry 18 months ago, we've been the benefactor of the soft economy and the increase in inquiries as a result of the higher levels of unemployment. And now I think what we're seeing is that those inquiries are starting to go back to normal levels. And when you compare that to prior year that was inflated, it ends up in a -- less of a growth and in some cases may be flat. So it's again, relative to what we got. We had a tailwind that's now starting to be maybe a neutral, but that neutral compared to a tailwind is a tougher comp.

componenttext: This is Kelly Flynn. Quick question, a lot’s been covered. But, Rick, you mentioned a bad debt. Could you just go back to that? headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the story is really wasn't a lot of change. The bad debt rate is about 3.1% on a year-to-date basis, which is a little bit higher than last year. But it's really driven by the additions of U.S. Education and DeVry Brazil into our family. We re
componenttext: Sure. Well, the story is really wasn't a lot of change. The bad debt rate is about 3.1% on a year-to-date basis, which is a little bit higher than last year. But it's really driven by the additions of U.S. Education and DeVry Brazil into our family. We really have not experienced any deterioration in our bad debt levels within our legacy operations. And it's all driven by the focus on our student accounts and our receivables. Our new system and the teams that are out there working on this day in day out are doing a fantastic job of providing customer service and working with these students on a day-to-day basis.

componenttext: You know, we’re always looking at that, Bob, and we look at that strategically. And we look at that long-term. So we are focused on delivering long-term results in terms of academic quality, enrolment growth and then ultimately the revenue and earnings that we talked about here. And so from an acquisition standpoint, we kind of feel like we built the framework of the house and acquisitions will continue to be a tool that we can use to build out the house, but less likely to get into a whole new area, when you look back to five or six years ago where we were building out this diversification strategy. And then other uses of cash include share repurchases and we've initiated our third plan there. And then of course we have a good -- we started to build a track record. We’re trying to build a long-term track record of dividend increases off of the relatively modest base that we started it. So those are the other uses of cash as well.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll speak to that. Co-location is something that's actually I'd say exceeding our even our internal expectations. And again, as with everything with DeVry, we're pretty conservative and took a slow approach at the beginning and tested it out in one
componenttext: Sure. I'll speak to that. Co-location is something that's actually I'd say exceeding our even our internal expectations. And again, as with everything with DeVry, we're pretty conservative and took a slow approach at the beginning and tested it out in one campus and then another and now given the results of that, that testing phase, we now are proceeding with confidence a little bit more aggressively. Just a few of the reasons that co-location leads to synergy, I’ll just use that word, include the ability to share the facilities, and you spread the facilities costs, including the libraries, the student common, the bookstore, many areas like that. You, in some cases, are able to have students co-sit across institutions like at Chamberlain College of Nursing and DeVry University. Students can actually co-sit in some courses, general education courses. So there's a sharing of resources there, which benefits our students and actually enriches the learning as well as having efficiencies. And many of the other student services can be shared or if not totally shared, there can be just some back office or common frameworks, common infrastructure: student services, financial aid, packaging. Financial aid packaging is pretty similar whether you're going to a nursing college or engineering program. When you do your financial aid packaging, it looks kind of the same and so there can be sharing there. So those are just to give you a little color and some of the reasons that the co-location is adding value and is part of this diversification strategy that we're pursuing here at DeVry.

componenttextpreview: Yes. It's interesting, Sara, that seems like ancient history, just a year ago or six or months ago whatever it was that everyone was all in a panic that the reduction in private lending, that was going to be the thing that was going to kill the private se
componenttext: Yes. It's interesting, Sara, that seems like ancient history, just a year ago or six or months ago whatever it was that everyone was all in a panic that the reduction in private lending, that was going to be the thing that was going to kill the private sector or whatever. And of course we said, we don't think that's going to happen and I think that's proven to be the case. So the private loans as a percent of total tuition or anyway you look at that, is very small, a couple of percent. So it hasn't -- it really has not had an impact on our current students or on our ability to attract new students. I think when you look at our student numbers you’ve seen that. So likewise the other part of your question about direct lending and it's really more of an issue for the banks or other people. It does not have an impact on the schools or on the students themselves. So we don't anticipate hiccups or problems. We've been working collaboratively with the Department of Education from an administrative point of view to ensure a seamless transition for our students. And that’s the key thing to make sure it doesn't impact the students.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fiscal 2010 Third Quarter Conference Call. My name is Jeremy and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to your host for
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fiscal 2010 Third Quarter Conference Call. My name is Jeremy and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Joan Bates, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may proceed.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy. And I'd like to welcome everyone to DeVry's Third Quarter Conference Call. With me today from DeVry senior leadership team are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Fina
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy. And I'd like to welcome everyone to DeVry's Third Quarter Conference Call. With me today from DeVry senior leadership team are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please be advised that statements made on this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements subject to the Safe Harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements generally can be identified by phrases such as DeVry, Inc. or its management has a view, objective or outlook, or that management believes, expects, anticipates, foresees, forecasts, estimates or other words or phrases of similar importance. Actual results may differ materially from those projected or implied. Potential risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause results to differ are described more fully in Item 1A, Risk Factors in the DeVry's most recent annual report on Form 10-K for the year ending June 30, 2009, and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on August 26, 2009. Telephone and webcast replays of the call are available until May 4, 2010. To access these replays, please refer to today's press release for information.
Daniel Hamburger will begin today's call with a quick overview followed by a review of the financial results by Rick Gunst. Daniel will then provide an operations update before opening up the call for your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Daniel.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Joan and thank you all for very much for joining us today. We're pleased to announce another quarter of strong performance, driven by the continued execution of our diversification strategy and by our operating philosophy. And namely, that i
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Joan and thank you all for very much for joining us today. We're pleased to announce another quarter of strong performance, driven by the continued execution of our diversification strategy and by our operating philosophy. And namely, that is that "Quality Leads to Growth". During the quarter, total undergraduate enrolment for DeVry University was up nearly 26% from the year-ago period, to a record of 66,909 students. These results flow directly from the investments we’ve made and the quality of our programs and services.
And we’re being careful stewards of our resources. An example of that is co-location. In today's press release, we highlighted two co-locations between DeVry University and Chamberlain College of Nursing in Crystal City, Virginia and in Chicago. These co-locations will further optimize utilization at those existing facilities and it’ll enhance academic student experience. 
Now if there was a theme this quarter, it would be healthcare. First of all, of course, we saw the passage of the new healthcare reform legislation. This law potentially means that 32 million more Americans will have health insurance by 2014.
This will put even more demand on an already strained system. Our schools are well positioned to educate the professionals who will be serving America's growing healthcare needs into the future. And Chamberlain College of Nursing is a great example of how we’ll help to meet this demand. Because even before this law was signed, it was forecasted that we would be 1 million nurses short by the end of this decade. And yet our nation's nursing schools are turning away almost 100,000 qualified applicants each and every year because there aren't enough seats to meet the demand. So Chamberlain is a great example of how DeVry and the private sector as a whole are meeting the capacity needs that we have. 
And likewise, in the world of medical education, it’s expected that we'll be 125,000 physicians short within 15 years. Ross University School of Medicine is helping to fulfill this critical need. And there's also a growing shortage of ancillary care and allied health professionals. And recently we made a change that we think paves the way to significantly meet the needs of these professionals as well because, during this quarter, we announced the name change of the two schools that make up U.S. Education: Western Career College and Apollo College. 
On July 1, the two will become Carrington College. It will be Carrington College California and Carrington College, respectively. And so taken together our medical and healthcare group is serving nearly 24,000 students and we’re a leading educator at all levels of healthcare, from the medical assistant to the nurse to the physician.
As millions of Americans become insured under healthcare reform, we expect to play an important role in meeting the need for healthcare professionals in this country. So with that brief introduction, let me turn the call over to Rick and we’ll go through the financial results.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon, everyone. We once again delivered strong revenue and earnings results this quarter, while making investments in academic quality. Our strong revenue growth continued to be a key source of operating leverage in improved
componenttext:
Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon, everyone. We once again delivered strong revenue and earnings results this quarter, while making investments in academic quality. Our strong revenue growth continued to be a key source of operating leverage in improved margins and profitably. 
Record quarterly revenue of $504 million was up about 29% versus prior year, with revenues still up 27%, excluding our acquisition of DeVry Brazil at April. Year-to-date revenue was up 32% and 26% when you exclude the impact of both DeVry Brazil and U.S. Education, which became part of DeVry in September of 2008.
Net income and earnings per share were both up about 60% in the quarter versus prior year on a reported basis, and up 51% after excluding a charge for a lease buyout from last year's results. Year-to-date earnings were up 63% on a reported basis and 59%, excluding last year's discrete item.
Pretax income margins for the first nine months was 22.1%, up 450 basis points versus the 17.6% margin achieved a year ago. We're obviously on our way to significantly surpass our historical full year peak margin of 17.1% this year and should exceed 20% by the end of the year as well. 
For your reference, third quarter results include expense related to share-based payments of approximately $2.2 million pretax or $1.8 million net of tax, a bit higher than last year. And our overall effective tax rate was 33.8% in the quarter and 33.3% year-to-date, up from our 30.4% rate for full fiscal year 2009, primarily due to the continued increase in domestic source income. 
Cost of Educational Services expense in the quarter increased by about 20% versus prior year, excluding last year's real estate charge and student service and administrative expense increased by 22%, both growing at double-digit rates, but less than revenue growth, with or without the acquisitions.
We continue to make prudent, targeted investments while still delivering leverage and efficiencies. With that let me now walk you through some of the key highlights of our operating segments, which are further detailed in our earnings release.
First, the Business, Technology, and Management segment continues to deliver very strong top and bottom line results. Revenue in the quarter was up about 29% versus prior year and 26% year-to-date, driven by the strong enrolment growth and increased retention, driven by our focus on student services. Segment operating income of $86 million in the quarter and $220 million year-to-date more than doubled versus prior year. The segment margin of 23.6% year-to-date was up about 900 basis points versus last year, reflecting the power of operating leverage on our cost base from the very strong top line growth.
Within the Medical and Healthcare segment, revenue was up 26% in the quarter driven by enrolment growth and pricing at Ross University and Chamberlain College of Nursing, along with good, but decelerating growth at U.S. Education. Third quarter operating income for the segment of $31 million was up about 19% versus last year. The margin was a bit lower than prior year driven by continued mix shift in the business mix within the segment with the growth of Chamberlain and U.S. Education, both which currently have lower margins than Ross University.
Also note that in Q4, we are planning increased spending associated with the start-ups for Chamberlain in Chicago and Crystal City, Virginia as well as cost associated with the name change and geographic expansion within U.S. Education. 
Our Professional Education segment results continue to reflect the impact of the soft economy on the accounting and finance professions, with some slight signs of improvement. Revenue was up 1% in the quarter and down about 2% year-to-date versus last year. Operating income was down about 15% in the quarter and down 18% year-to-date. Once again, we don't expect performance to improve materially in calendar 2010, or really until the economic recovery takes hold and positively impacts hiring and training within these professions.
Lastly, our Other Educational Services segment contributed about $14 million of revenue in the quarter, but with an operating loss of $1.4 million. Advanced Academics had increased marketing spending in the quarter to drive future growth, and our fiscal third quarter represents a seasonal low point for tuition revenue at DeVry Brazil. No classes were held for most of January, given the academic calendar in Brazil resulting in only about two months of revenue recognition in the quarter. This segment is expected to deliver operating income again in the fourth quarter.
Shifting to cash flow in the balance sheet. Cash flow from operations for the first nine months was $481 million versus $288 million last year driven by improved earnings and working capital. These strong cash flow results drove our cash and marketable security balance to $502 million at the end of the third quarter, compared to $297 million last year. And our outstanding debt was $45 million, which is level with last quarter and down from $135 million last year.
Capital spending through the first nine months was $102 million, about double the amount we spent last year. The spending has been focused on project Delta, which we believe will further enhance our ability to provide best-in-class service to our students, as well as on facility improvements within DeVry University and U.S. Education and expansion within Ross University and Chamberlain College of Nursing. 
We also completed our home office move in January to two new locations here in the western suburbs of Chicago. We’re committed to investing in educational technology and capacity needed to serve our students, and we've been successful in completing project spending this year. Total capital spending is expected to be in the $130 million to $140 million range by the end of the year.
Our net accounts receivable balance continued to run lower than prior year despite our strong revenue growth. Net accounts receivable decreased to $156 million versus $180 million last year. Receivables per account within DeVry University were actually down compared to the balances last year as well as two years ago. 
Our year-to-date bad debt rate increased slightly versus last year to 3.1%, driven by the U.S. Ed. and DeVry Brazil additions. We have not experienced really any significant deterioration with bad debt in our legacy operations.
These results can be attributed to the impact of our financial aid processing system, focus on customer service and a tremendous effort of our campus and student finance teams. And I really do want to commend these people. When you factor in the tough economy to bring down receivables per account, let alone total receivables is a huge, huge achievement. 
Finally during the quarter, we began executing our third share repurchase program buying back about 100,000 shares at an average cost of $63.37 per share. So that concludes my comments and the strong results for the quarter and the first nine months of the year. Fiscal 2010 is going to be a breakthrough year for the organization, significantly surpassing our long-term financial goals given the power of operating leverage. The fourth quarter will continue to show margin improvement, albeit at a lower rate of growth than we achieved in the nine-month period. 
As we look ahead to fiscal 2011, we expect the Business, Technology and Management segment to continue to deliver strong revenue and earnings growth, driven by the flow-through of our recent strong enrollment growth and continued operating leverage. The Medical and Healthcare segment earnings, however, will likely be flat to maybe even slightly down next year. This is driven by capacity and enrollment constraints within Ross' Medical School that Daniel will discuss in a few minutes, along with start-up costs associated with geographic expansion at Chamberlain and U.S. Education. 
In addition, we anticipate existing campus growth at U.S. Education to slow down as the economy recovers and unemployment levels decline. Finally, we hope to see improved top and bottom line results within Professional Education segment as the economy recovers and anticipate that the Other Educational Services segment will contribute more to revenue and earnings growth.
Overall, our diversification is serving us well as we expect to deliver results in line with our long-term financial goals for DeVry Inc. of double-digit revenue growth and roughly 20% earnings per share growth in fiscal 2011. With that, let me now turn the call back to Daniel for some color on the operating results.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Rick. Let me start with Business, Technology and Management segment, which, of course, is DeVry University and its Keller Graduate School of Management. This is another strong quarter of positive academic outcomes and excellent enrolment gro
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Rick. Let me start with Business, Technology and Management segment, which, of course, is DeVry University and its Keller Graduate School of Management. This is another strong quarter of positive academic outcomes and excellent enrolment growth. 
We were especially pleased to see contributions across all curriculum areas, degree levels and delivery modes. Let me give you some color on that. Total undergraduate enrolment in DeVry University’s Business programs grew 22%, Technology programs grew 27% and the Healthcare programs grew 46%.
We're also seeing significant enrolment growth at the graduate level as coursetakers rose 17% for the January session and more than 15% in March. 17% is the highest growth rate in total graduate coursetakers since 2003. We believe this demonstrates the strong return on the investments we're making to raise awareness of the quality of our graduate degree programs. 
The total number of online coursetakers at DeVry University the March session, this includes undergraduate and graduate together, increased 21.5% from the prior year and the campuses and centers grew nicely well. So we're seeing contributions to our overall strong growth rates at DeVry University from all channels, that’s curriculum areas, degree levels and delivery modes.
DeVry University continues to position itself as the career university and in line with this we've making investments in expanding career services for our students and hiring more career advisors. The most recent employment rate for DeVry University graduates in the active job market, who are employed within their field of study within six months of graduation, remained steady at 87.7%. And we believe this demonstrates that employers continue to see tremendous value in our graduates, despite the continued weakness in the job market. 
We also accelerated the rollout of our next generation student central location to better support our students from the time they enroll until they graduate. This innovative student central concept will be in all of our campuses by the end of fiscal 2010.
And DeVry University is continuing to invest in new location. Thus far in fiscal 2011, we expect to open new campuses near Houston and Phoenix as part of our plans to open five or six new locations in total at DeVry University next year. 
Now the key to DeVry University's strong performance is the quality of the learning experience we offer to our students. And the backbone of providing that quality is our highly-talented faculty. So I'm particularly proud of the talent we have teaching at DeVry University and wanted to highlight that beginning this month we'll be establishing a recurring faculty symposium. This will be another great arena for DeVry University’s thought leaders to learn from one another, presenting white papers and essential topics such as student retention, blended learning and many others.
Now I'd like to update you on Project Delta. As most of you know, this is a major student systems migration that will greatly improve productivity and student service at both DeVry University and at Chamberlain College of Nursing. Now as with any major systems project I've ever been involved in, we've experienced some delays and cost overruns. But as we’ve said many times, success means getting it right. And that's the most important thing. We will not launch any of the phases until they're fully tested and ready. Now we do expect initial phases to rollout in the coming months and we're excited about the capabilities Project Delta will provide to us and to our students.
Let me turn now to our Medical and Healthcare segment. At Ross University, we’ve continued to see growth as new student enrolment in January at the Med and Vet schools was up more than 14% and total student enrolment increased 8% from year ago. As those of you have been following us know, part of the growth strategy at Ross University School of Medicine is the development of a clinical education center located in Freeport, Grand Bahamas. One of the attractions of the clinical site, which opened in January of last year, was that it was expected to play a role in alleviating capacity constraints at Ross' main campus in Dominica. This hasn't gone according to plan. There's a few reasons for this. 
One reason has to do with student’s reaction to a funding difference. Title IV funding has not been available to students studying in Freeport. We knew this and so as a result, we developed an institutional loan alternative that alleviated any impact per student. But from a perception point of view, the fact that there was a difference, lead to a more cautious outlook on the part of existing students who were considering Freeport. 
And there was also a delay in the California review process. So just background on that. Four states, including California, require approval of international medical school programs in order to license graduates to participate in clinicals in their states. They also require notification for new locations. So Ross made the proper notification, but California later concluded that Freeport was subject to a more extensive evaluation process. Now we've heard nothing that would indicate that the California Medical Board has any concerns about the Freeport location or its academics or operations. It's just that it’s a process that you have to go through and we hope to receive formal approval by the end of the year.
And these things have combined to reduce the number of students in Freeport well below what we had been planning, which means that we need to add investment and resources in Dominica. So as we continue to work on the Freeport location, we're adding capacity in Dominica. We're adding additional classrooms, laboratory, space and faculty. We are committed to providing the resources our students need to receive a high-quality education. 
What all of this will mean is we're lowering new student enrolment for at least the upcoming May and September terms. And we’ll keep you informed of our progress on all these fronts as they unfold. In the meantime, we expect that our well-diversified portfolio of programs will enable DeVry overall to achieve its long-term performance goals. And to give you some perspective on that, we anticipate that the slowing of enrolment growth at Ross will affect earnings by approximately $5 million in fiscal 2011.
So we believe this is a prudent step and will allow Ross to manage through the near term and prepare for growth longer term. The situation reminds me of when we first acquired Ross and we made the conscious decision to slow enrolment growth for a time in order to improve outcomes for students. That investment laid the foundation for the excellent academic outcomes and the strong growth in applications that we've seen ever since. 
But here, although it's a different situation, we're making a similar investment for the short term that will allow us to better serve our existing student population and manage for long-term growth. 
So moving on within the segment, our Chamberlain College of Nursing continues to grow as enrolment was up 72% over the prior year. Chamberlain experienced strong growth at each of its campuses and across all of its programs. We continue to invest in geographic expansion at Chamberlain. 
For the two co-locations I mentioned earlier, we recently received approval from the Boards of Nursing in both Illinois and in Virginia. Both campuses received wonderful feedback from accreditor and nursing board review team.
Last week, I had the honor of keynoting the ribbon-cutting ceremony at the relocated campus in St. Louis, which is yet another co-location with DeVry University. As we toured this wonderful campus, it felt like we were in a hospital with nursing stations and ICU, patient simulators. And these simulators give our students the opportunity to learn in a life-like yet safe environment and provide an excellent academic experience. I discussed with the local government officials what a privilege it is to open a new 55,000 square-foot plus facility with state-of-the-art equipment at a time when public universities are capacity constrained. 
And then at Apollo College and Western Career College, soon-to-be Carrington Colleges, new enrolments dipped 2% while total enrollments were up 10% for the period. New enrollments were affected by several factors including a moderation in enrolment as the economy recovers, and a tougher comparison to last year's very strong growth, execution issues, which have been addressed, and near-term capacity constraints as we develop new locations. 
Later this year, U.S. Education is going to going to co-locate with DeVry University in Pomona, California. That'll be our first location in Southern California for what’s soon-to-be-called Carrington College of California.
Turning to our Professional Education segment. The economy continues to affect the accounting and finance fields that Becker Professional Education serves. But we're seeing early indications that the worst is over as our CPA segment is beginning to show modest growth. We believe Becker is well positioned for long-term growth. This is evident when you look at Accounting Today's list of the Top 100 Firms and see that Becker has relationships in place with 97 of them. 
Our Stalla Review for the CFA exam recently entered into partnerships with the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and with UBS to serve as their preferred partner. 
And then finally moving to our Other Educational Services segment. I’d like to comment on DeVry Brazil. Total enrollments were flat because of tougher comparisons in graduate student enrollment and the delay in the rollout of several new programs. 
Even though it's small today, we believe DeVry Brazil continues to have great potential for long-term growth. Right now, we're focused on building our infrastructure, including student services and online delivery, in order to build upon our quality offerings there and to foster future growth.
During the quarter, we received approvals for numerous new courses in the healthcare field in Brazil, including nursing, physiotherapy and nutrition and these should contribute positively to the future enrollment growth. We're also exploring further expansion options to the new locations. 
And I'd like to mention that we're building upon a strong foundation of academic quality at DeVry Brazil. For example, based on outcomes of the OAB exam, which is the equivalent of the bar exam in the U.S., for the second year in a row, Ruy Barbosa student test scores were number one in Salvador and number one among all private institutions in Brazil countrywide.
And so to wrap it up, overall, we're very pleased with the results in the quarter as more than anything they demonstrate that our diversification strategy is serving us well. While we discussed some near-term challenges at Ross University and a countercyclical moderation at U.S. Education, these are more than offset by the outperformance at DeVry University and at Chamberlain College of Nursing. 
So taken together, we're very well-positioned to meet our near term and our long-term goals. So with that, we'd be happy to take questions. Joan?

componenttextpreview: Well, not to the same magnitude we’ve had this year, I can tell you that much. But we do anticipate with the enrolment growth we've seen lately that, that will carry forward into next year and then the year after. We continue to give us good double-digi
componenttext: Well, not to the same magnitude we’ve had this year, I can tell you that much. But we do anticipate with the enrolment growth we've seen lately that, that will carry forward into next year and then the year after. We continue to give us good double-digit revenue growth and then as we go forward, it's going to be more focused on continued efficiencies to enable us to continue to drive overall operating margin improvement. I think it will come more from SS&A in the future than from cost of instruction as we continue to invest in academic quality.

componenttext: Sure. We have graduation rates of 31% at DeVry University, 30% at Chamberlain College [inaudible] and 67% at U.S. Education. And so I always urge caution in interpreting those. And also, we need to compare those to institutions who serve similar populations of students, often with several of the Department of Education's defined risk factors and other factors like that. So those are the numbers that we have.

componenttext: I would say that was the most significant occurrence of something like that. And we have a really strong management team at U.S. Education, soon-to-be Carrington Colleges. I am very confident in that management team and we continue to strengthen the management team. As you see in the press release, a new member of the team and we feel very good about how we run things there, very, very strong operating. But even with that, blips can occur from time to time and that's what we saw there.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, when you two called out countercyclicality for U.S. Ed, I know you also said it was other factors as well. I kind of think maybe it’s still early in the unemployment rate to start to crawl to countercyclicality. How would you judge the countercy
componenttext: Daniel, when you two called out countercyclicality for U.S. Ed, I know you also said it was other factors as well. I kind of think maybe it’s still early in the unemployment rate to start to crawl to countercyclicality. How would you judge the countercyclicality as affecting U.S. Ed? And do you see countercyclicality becoming a headwind for any other unit at DeVry?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's really U.S. Education or soon-to-be Carrington Colleges that's been the most countercyclical within our family here at DeVry. And this is as we've said many times, that that really balances out some of the other parts of our family where we're pr
componenttext: No, it's really U.S. Education or soon-to-be Carrington Colleges that's been the most countercyclical within our family here at DeVry. And this is as we've said many times, that that really balances out some of the other parts of our family where we're pro-cyclical, like Becker, or areas where we're completely non-cyclical, like the medical school, nursing school, veterinary school. So from an overall DeVry perspective we can continue to -- and the most important thing is we can continue to achieve our goals, even if there is a little bit of, and I wouldn't call it a headwind as much as just a less of the tailwind that we've been seeing at the shorter term programs that we have at Carrington Colleges.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And could you also give a comment about student persistence rates going forward? What would be the drivers there?
componenttext: And could you also give a comment about student persistence rates going forward? What would be the drivers there?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, student persistence and retention is a huge focus for us from an academic perspective at all of our colleges and universities. And the drivers there would be things like this innovative student central model that we have put in place at DeVry Univer
componenttext: Well, student persistence and retention is a huge focus for us from an academic perspective at all of our colleges and universities. And the drivers there would be things like this innovative student central model that we have put in place at DeVry University and are rolling out to full rollout to provide the kind of student support services, academic advising, student services, part-time jobs, career services, financial aid services to support our students. That's what our students and graduates tell us helps to make a difference in helping them to persist and to graduate. It's providing that kind of support service that unfortunately, aren’t always provided at some of the public institutions. And that would be, I’d say, the number one area that is going to help us with persistence, along with the other investments that we pointed to in terms of just academics within the classroom, investments that we’re making to support our faculty. I’d point to all those factors.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think student persistence will be up because of those factors? Or will it be challenged because of any countercyclical effects?
componenttext: And do you think student persistence will be up because of those factors? Or will it be challenged because of any countercyclical effects?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, no. We think we can continue to make -- we've had improvements in student persistence and we've been doing that through the economic cycles. We'll continue to focus on that through the economic cycles as well.
componenttext: Oh, no. We think we can continue to make -- we've had improvements in student persistence and we've been doing that through the economic cycles. We'll continue to focus on that through the economic cycles as well.
