componenttextpreview: No, it certainly can. There's nothing that would preclude that.
componenttext: No, it certainly can. There's nothing that would preclude that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to Ross, could you just talk a little bit about the impact from the new rules that are being proposed for U.S. aid to students at foreign institutions. I know that some of the rules are talking about raising the percentage of graduates that m
componenttext: With respect to Ross, could you just talk a little bit about the impact from the new rules that are being proposed for U.S. aid to students at foreign institutions. I know that some of the rules are talking about raising the percentage of graduates that must pass the U.S. medical license exam. I know you guys have very good metrics on that but can you just maybe talk a minute about what if any impact that would have on Ross?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, and again, the overarching comment is until the rules are finalized, we can't and won't speculate on the impact to DeVry on this program, students and so forth. But you're right, the sort of 75% benchmark is out there, and the U.S. MLE Step 1 pass r
componenttext: Sure, and again, the overarching comment is until the rules are finalized, we can't and won't speculate on the impact to DeVry on this program, students and so forth. But you're right, the sort of 75% benchmark is out there, and the U.S. MLE Step 1 pass rates for Ross University School of Medicine students are well over 90%. So that just gives you an indication and a feel for how we might view that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question's from the line of Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question's from the line of Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back on Ross. In the press release you talk about moderating new enrollment growth while the initiatives are completed. Do you have some sort of time frame when that will be done?
componenttext: Just to circle back on Ross. In the press release you talk about moderating new enrollment growth while the initiatives are completed. Do you have some sort of time frame when that will be done?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've said, it'll be at least through January here, and we'll keep you posted as we go. Some of this is within our own control and we take responsibility for that. Some of them are outside our control and we just have to work through the regulator
componenttext: Yes. As we've said, it'll be at least through January here, and we'll keep you posted as we go. Some of this is within our own control and we take responsibility for that. Some of them are outside our control and we just have to work through the regulatory, the accreditation processes. So until we have more capacity, we're going to do the right thing for our students and limit the enrollment growth to that which we can support and continue to maintain and enhance the quality educational outcomes.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could switch gears to Chamberlain, you had some phenomenal growth numbers. Is it possible to break out just same-school growth both in terms of new enrollment and total enrollment? And I'm just also wondering how placement trends are for those school
componenttext: If I could switch gears to Chamberlain, you had some phenomenal growth numbers. Is it possible to break out just same-school growth both in terms of new enrollment and total enrollment? And I'm just also wondering how placement trends are for those schools?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, for Chamberlain, in terms of placement -- and by the way if you'll forgive me, Jeff, we like to use the word employment results, and it's very important, it's not just trying to be cute or anything, and words matter. But we're very adamant internall
componenttext: Sure, for Chamberlain, in terms of placement -- and by the way if you'll forgive me, Jeff, we like to use the word employment results, and it's very important, it's not just trying to be cute or anything, and words matter. But we're very adamant internally and externally when we talk to our teams and we talk to students. We don't place graduates. We provide them with the skills to conduct a lifelong career search. In today's world, most of us will go through career changes more than one time. So we make sure that we educate students on how to conduct a job search, and they go and get that job, we don't place them. So we like to use the word employment statistics or graduate employment statistics. And they're strong at Chamberlain. Obviously, there's a lot of need and that's only going to grow for nursing graduates. And in terms of the growth, I'm not able to break that out in terms of a same campus, new campus online, we just haven't broken that out yet.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next, you have the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.
componenttext: And next, you have the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple questions on the margins. First of all in the Professional business with the revenue I think stabilized and I guess quite a bit better than stabilized this quarter, is it reasonable to expect the profitability to continue to decline there
componenttext: I guess a couple questions on the margins. First of all in the Professional business with the revenue I think stabilized and I guess quite a bit better than stabilized this quarter, is it reasonable to expect the profitability to continue to decline there as you're making investments? Or is there some change in the business model? Or would it be reasonable to expect that margins might start to flatten out if you continue to have positive revenue there?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gary, hi, it's Rick. As we look forward to this fiscal year, we don't expect robust improvement on the top line but we hope that we'd see some growth on the top line and likewise at the bottom line. And margins being about flat, would be I guess our
componenttext: Yes, Gary, hi, it's Rick. As we look forward to this fiscal year, we don't expect robust improvement on the top line but we hope that we'd see some growth on the top line and likewise at the bottom line. And margins being about flat, would be I guess our general perspective on that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the DeVry University segment, another incredible performance on the margins and the incremental operating margin. I guess it seems reasonable that revenue growth could decelerate quite a bit but you probably still have pretty healthy incremental ma
componenttext: And on the DeVry University segment, another incredible performance on the margins and the incremental operating margin. I guess it seems reasonable that revenue growth could decelerate quite a bit but you probably still have pretty healthy incremental margins. Is that the right way to think about it and we've got some more margin gains in store? Are there any sort of big, big investments that you're planning to layer on that might really decelerate the pace of the gains in the next few quarters?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we will continue to have margin improvement in that segment but not at the same level by any means that we've seen this past year in fiscal '10 or fiscal '09 for that matter because as you mentioned the top line growth will begin to slow dow
componenttext: Well, I think we will continue to have margin improvement in that segment but not at the same level by any means that we've seen this past year in fiscal '10 or fiscal '09 for that matter because as you mentioned the top line growth will begin to slow down, still be very robust but not be as strong as it was this past year, and the one major investment that will start to realize the expense probably would be the Project Delta. The depreciation and the training costs we're going to have in fiscal '11 will be hitting, a good portion of those costs hit DeVry University or the Business, Technology and Management segment directly. But still with all that, we would expect to see our expenses grow at a slower pace than the top line growth and see margin improvement next year, just not the same level of improvement that we saw, the dramatic improvement this year.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one last question. I understand the desire to grow and diversify and I think it's the right strategy, but adding $50 million to the buyback given how weak the stock has been and how strong your balance sheet and cash flows are, it just doesn
componenttext: And then just one last question. I understand the desire to grow and diversify and I think it's the right strategy, but adding $50 million to the buyback given how weak the stock has been and how strong your balance sheet and cash flows are, it just doesn't really move the needle. I guess I wondered, Daniel, if you could speak on behalf of the board sort of why not consider being more aggressive given that you've got an awful lot of cash to deploy in M&A or other strategies as well?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are mindful of all the potential uses of cash and we are DeVry, remember. So there is a conservative Midwest attitude here that has served us very well over the long term. And we've been criticized many times in the short-term. But over the long-
componenttext: Well, we are mindful of all the potential uses of cash and we are DeVry, remember. So there is a conservative Midwest attitude here that has served us very well over the long term. And we've been criticized many times in the short-term. But over the long-term, people usually say, "Oh, now I get it." So yes, there are acquisition opportunities, there are investment opportunities in quality and growth initiatives. And then certainly, there is money still left in the third share repurchase program and now here launching a fourth in four years, our board felt was appropriate, so it's actually more than $50 million going forward. But the main thing is yes, the intent of it – and maybe we weren't successful in demonstrating that to you – but you should know, the sentiment behind it was as Rick said earlier, that we certainly believe in making that investment in those shares at these levels.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess I would add, Gary, that if you look at this program we're currently almost more than halfway completed, the third program, that was authorized just several months ago and it was supposed to last for two years, but we have it on a structured pr
componenttext: And I guess I would add, Gary, that if you look at this program we're currently almost more than halfway completed, the third program, that was authorized just several months ago and it was supposed to last for two years, but we have it on a structured program so that we're buying back more shares as the price fluctuates down and thanks to all the negative cloud that's been out there, we've been more active in the market and that's why we're going to be completed with this third program likely in another month or so. And so the board authorized another $50 million and we'll maybe, if things don't move we'll complete that quicker and that doesn't mean that they can't add another one on top of that. So I wouldn't read into the $50 million anything more than it's just a continuation of the program and we'll be buying back more at these attractive levels.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next we have Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.
componenttext: And next we have Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I think one of the huge highlights here is how much persistence has soared and Daniel, of course, I heard your original comments of why that's happening with Student Central. My question is about sustainability. Do you feel like the next few semesters sho
componenttext: I think one of the huge highlights here is how much persistence has soared and Daniel, of course, I heard your original comments of why that's happening with Student Central. My question is about sustainability. Do you feel like the next few semesters should have a similar rise in persistence? And how far do you think we are along in benefiting from the effects of Student Central?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well thanks, Andrew, for those comments. We're very proud of that increase in persistence. That's what we're here for, to support our students and help them to persist through to graduation. And especially for many of the students that we serve in many of
componenttext: Well thanks, Andrew, for those comments. We're very proud of that increase in persistence. That's what we're here for, to support our students and help them to persist through to graduation. And especially for many of the students that we serve in many of our schools, who are often first in their family to go to college, and you think about it, came from a family that was very fortunate, you were going to college and there's a big support network there. That's not America today. There's many, many students who don't have that support network. And so we have to provide that level of support and we have made a huge investment in providing those kinds of support services, and that's going to continue. And I can say that the improvements that we've seen is not the end of our goals. Our goals are still higher. So I can't predict in the near term exactly what that translates to but I can tell you that we do aim higher in that regard.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Right, but Daniel, just speak again. I mean, this semester was just such a large rise. I mean, by my calculations it was actually the largest year-over-year rise that DeVry has seen going years back. Do you feel like that type of rise in any way is an ano
componenttext: Right, but Daniel, just speak again. I mean, this semester was just such a large rise. I mean, by my calculations it was actually the largest year-over-year rise that DeVry has seen going years back. Do you feel like that type of rise in any way is an anomaly or do you feel like that's in general how we're entering the fall semester, for example?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think it's an anomaly or sort of an accident. It's due to a lot of hard work on the part of our professors and all of our people. And I don't think it's going to just sort of poof and then go away. I think we're going to continue to be persis
componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's an anomaly or sort of an accident. It's due to a lot of hard work on the part of our professors and all of our people. And I don't think it's going to just sort of poof and then go away. I think we're going to continue to be persistent in improving persistence.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: So you think it's going to be a theme in the current fiscal year?
componenttext: So you think it's going to be a theme in the current fiscal year?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a huge theme and it's job one in our strategy. That is the strategy number one, achieving our high-quality academic outcomes in student services is all in support of persistence, and it's important to recognize this is [ph] (59:40) academic quality a
componenttext: It's a huge theme and it's job one in our strategy. That is the strategy number one, achieving our high-quality academic outcomes in student services is all in support of persistence, and it's important to recognize this is [ph] (59:40) academic quality and student services. We have to match the excellence in the classroom with excellence in all of the surrounding services that go around that. And it's a combination of both. World-class customer service, which is not something that you get from many public sector universities and others. That is the winning formula.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next you have the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.
componenttext: And next you have the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: First, a couple of quick numbers questions. Last quarter I believe you said that you thought 20% EPS growth in fiscal '11 was reasonable. Is that still your thinking?
componenttext: First, a couple of quick numbers questions. Last quarter I believe you said that you thought 20% EPS growth in fiscal '11 was reasonable. Is that still your thinking?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said at the end of my comments, Corey, looking at 20% earnings growth, the challenge might be that given the increase in our tax rate that we anticipate given the fact that our domestic source income will be growing faster than the international
componenttext: Yes, as I said at the end of my comments, Corey, looking at 20% earnings growth, the challenge might be that given the increase in our tax rate that we anticipate given the fact that our domestic source income will be growing faster than the international income because Ross will be flattish, even down. That puts a little pressure on the EPS number but operating income should be still in that 20% range.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the thought about high single-digit growth at DeVry University, you're talking about overall enrollment, right, not necessarily new student enrollment?
componenttext: And in terms of the thought about high single-digit growth at DeVry University, you're talking about overall enrollment, right, not necessarily new student enrollment?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, over time, new students and total student growth tends to come together. That period I mentioned in the '90s was 7.5% for new student growth and 7.5% of total student growth. So as it works through the pipeline it tends to equilibrate.
componenttext: Well, over time, new students and total student growth tends to come together. That period I mentioned in the '90s was 7.5% for new student growth and 7.5% of total student growth. So as it works through the pipeline it tends to equilibrate.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering, if you look over the next couple of terms, the comps get tougher on the new student enrollments. I'm just wondering if people should be keeping that in mind and looking for a deceleration over the next couple terms in that metric from
componenttext: I'm just wondering, if you look over the next couple of terms, the comps get tougher on the new student enrollments. I'm just wondering if people should be keeping that in mind and looking for a deceleration over the next couple terms in that metric from what you just reported?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't give guidance in that regard but as you start to level off in that, we've been doing better than that for the past many quarters and periods; wouldn't be surprised if maybe we dip a little bit below. But again, the good news is given our p
componenttext: Again, we don't give guidance in that regard but as you start to level off in that, we've been doing better than that for the past many quarters and periods; wouldn't be surprised if maybe we dip a little bit below. But again, the good news is given our persistence that we just talked about, and our strong pipeline of new students we've had over the past several semesters, that should help our total enrollment growth that drives our total revenues.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And then another topic. DeVry certainly has a good reputation in the industry. Could you just talk about what controls you have in place to ensure that none of your admissions personnel are misrepresenting anything to students and how confident are you th
componenttext: And then another topic. DeVry certainly has a good reputation in the industry. Could you just talk about what controls you have in place to ensure that none of your admissions personnel are misrepresenting anything to students and how confident are you that those controls are preventing any such misrepresentation?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take that, Corey. Thanks for that question. DeVry does have a very robust multilayered compliance program. We've had that for years and decades. The details of it go far beyond the time that we have available on this call. And although we know
componenttext: Sure, I'll take that, Corey. Thanks for that question. DeVry does have a very robust multilayered compliance program. We've had that for years and decades. The details of it go far beyond the time that we have available on this call. And although we know our compliance program is very effective overall, we also know that exceptions can occur. That's true for any organization. So what's equally important is what we do when an error occurs or a problem occurs. And the answer is we take immediate corrective action. We walk the walk and we talk the talk on that. Many examples and we talk about that explicitly within DeVry as part of continuing to maintain and enhance our culture of accountability and integrity. An example, several years ago we became aware of an issue at one camp that related to this and once we investigated it, we promptly notified the Department of Education and terminated the employees who were responsible in that case. And so we do the right thing and we deal with it and I think that's what any organization has to do. I was at a meeting of business leaders a couple of months ago and Jeff Immelt of GE was there and he said, "Look, I got 250,000 employees. I can guarantee you as sure as we're sitting here, 25 or 30 of them are doing something that I don't want them to be doing. The key is making sure that's an exception but also making sure what you do about it when it happens." So these things can happen. But the key is how you deal with that and the key is how do you make sure you've got an overarching training and compliance program to ensure that, that is very much the exception.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next we have the line of Kelly Flynn with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And next we have the line of Kelly Flynn with Crédit Suisse.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to Carrington, last quarter, I know you talked about the execution issues impacting starts, but you also talked about countercyclicality, which is not something that you mentioned this quarter. Can you just address what role you think that is
componenttext: With respect to Carrington, last quarter, I know you talked about the execution issues impacting starts, but you also talked about countercyclicality, which is not something that you mentioned this quarter. Can you just address what role you think that is playing? And maybe with hindsight even what role it played last quarter? And how you think of that overall? And then actually related to that, in response to Amy's question you said you think starts growth can reaccelerate. My question is, do you think it will reaccelerate in this coming quarter?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kelly, and if we've been a little bit, and I've been a little bit wishy-washy on that, I would accept that criticism because it is a little hard to read the tea leaves of the economy right now. Looked like it was getting better and now, just today we
componenttext: Yes, Kelly, and if we've been a little bit, and I've been a little bit wishy-washy on that, I would accept that criticism because it is a little hard to read the tea leaves of the economy right now. Looked like it was getting better and now, just today we had new unemployment claims go up again. So everybody's getting all squirrely about the economy and worried about that, and might that have a countercyclical tailwind, reemergence for those kinds of programs at Carrington. Again, for the DeVry family overall, not really countercyclical; but for Carrington specifically, yes, a little bit countercyclical. And at the same time we've had internal things going on so it's been a little tough for us to get as strong of a read on that as we normally would because we have data points clouding our instrumentation here. The thing that is particular to us is this name change. We do think that's going to be strong for us. The early read is a very positive response to that and an increase in inquiries from prospective students. So yes, it's possible, and certainly that's what we're working toward, is to turn that around and get [ph] (1:05:59) the positive new student and of course maintain total student enrollment growth at Carrington Colleges Group.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't fully understand. I mean on the countercyclicality thing, do you think it played a role in the past couple quarters or not? I understand broadly it could play a role and it is a bit uncertain but I mean, looking at the past two quarters, did it pl
componenttext: I don't fully understand. I mean on the countercyclicality thing, do you think it played a role in the past couple quarters or not? I understand broadly it could play a role and it is a bit uncertain but I mean, looking at the past two quarters, did it play a role in your view or not?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: What I'm saying is that over the past period of time, we had a countercyclical tailwind at Carrington. Yes, we had that. And what we said last time, we're starting to see that probably begin to flag. And I still say that, I don't think you're going to see
componenttext: What I'm saying is that over the past period of time, we had a countercyclical tailwind at Carrington. Yes, we had that. And what we said last time, we're starting to see that probably begin to flag. And I still say that, I don't think you're going to see it quite as strong as it was in the depths of the great recession. And all I'm adding to that is, at the same time we have our own internal execution issues on the negative side, plus we've got the name change on the positive side, so that's three factors all sort of merging together. When you have that it makes it a little bit more difficult to read. And so I accept that we haven't been crystal clear as we usually like to be on that, but overall that would be the way we characterize it.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: A quick, I guess an easier one for Rick. On the tax rate for next year, I just want to make sure I heard you correctly. You think it will be a few hundred basis points higher?
componenttext: A quick, I guess an easier one for Rick. On the tax rate for next year, I just want to make sure I heard you correctly. You think it will be a few hundred basis points higher?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I said it could be around 200 basis points higher.
componenttext: I said it could be around 200 basis points higher.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Next, we have the line of Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next, we have the line of Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: On risk factors per students, I would assume that the people at Legacy, Apollo and Western have higher risk factors. Under obviously the gainful employment proposal it becomes a little more risky for a company to accept those types of students. Has that c
componenttext: On risk factors per students, I would assume that the people at Legacy, Apollo and Western have higher risk factors. Under obviously the gainful employment proposal it becomes a little more risky for a company to accept those types of students. Has that changed your view on admissions standards for the lower level degrees?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we still think there is a very strong need, an unmet need for career-oriented education in the career college segment in particular. We still think there's a very strong return on investment for those students. And so we are not looking at making any
componenttext: No, we still think there is a very strong need, an unmet need for career-oriented education in the career college segment in particular. We still think there's a very strong return on investment for those students. And so we are not looking at making any changes to, really to anything in that regard. And so we're going to continue to power along and just keep focused on serving those students.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, you've collected quite a bit of salary data over the history of your company and you have quite a good amount of detail because of accrediting. How do you think that salary data stacks up against Social Security data or IRS data? How do you thin
componenttext: And then, you've collected quite a bit of salary data over the history of your company and you have quite a good amount of detail because of accrediting. How do you think that salary data stacks up against Social Security data or IRS data? How do you think it matches up against potential IRS or Social Security data? Do you think it could be a big deviation?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's probably in a range but the real answer is I'm really just speculating, because I don't know and we just don't have that data. Until we get the data and we see it, we can't really say for sure.
componenttext: No, it's probably in a range but the real answer is I'm really just speculating, because I don't know and we just don't have that data. Until we get the data and we see it, we can't really say for sure.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And we have the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And we have the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you guys please address just how you're looking at pricing on a go-forward basis? Any change to whatever you've spoken in the past with regard to how you think about it?
componenttext: Could you guys please address just how you're looking at pricing on a go-forward basis? Any change to whatever you've spoken in the past with regard to how you think about it?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, not really, no. The way we look at tuition and the pricing is from at least two lenses. One is the competitive set and our schools often compete actually a lot less with other publicly held organizations that you might be very familiar with and muc
componenttext: Scott, not really, no. The way we look at tuition and the pricing is from at least two lenses. One is the competitive set and our schools often compete actually a lot less with other publicly held organizations that you might be very familiar with and much more so with many of the publicly sector institutions, state schools, and at Carrington it might be at the community college level, for example. And so we look at the competitive tuition increases that are out there and we've certainly seeing pretty big numbers; here in Illinois, I think like 11%, and I've seen mid-teens, even in California over 30% tuition increases. And so that certainly puts one perspective on it. Like in any endeavor in life, you look at what the competitors and what the others are doing. And then the other lens that we put on it is more internal, looking at our programs and the value proposition that our students receive. And so we've I think previously shared ROI, or ROE, our return an educational investment for our students. We've shared how over a 30 year period of time, if you take a look at the salaries that our graduates achieved, the kind of return on investments that they get, even with paying the tuition that they pay. And that's for many of our schools in the high 20s, even over 30% return on investment. Again, other than DeVry shares I'm not sure what else I could find that would have such a high return on investment. So we look at it from both those perspectives and that continues, no change there.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to CapEx, looks like the guidance for next year up $10 million to $20 million year-over-year. Not taking this too far out but is that going to be an unusually high year or is this consistent on the trend? And what are the components that are t
componenttext: With regard to CapEx, looks like the guidance for next year up $10 million to $20 million year-over-year. Not taking this too far out but is that going to be an unusually high year or is this consistent on the trend? And what are the components that are taking us higher? Is it primarily stuff in the Caribbean or Project Delta? Rick, could you just give us a little elaboration? Thanks.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. For next year, we've got the continuation of Project Delta and there might be some carryover into fiscal '12 but the bulk of that spending will be behind us as we exit fiscal '11. But the other main reason for the continued higher level of spending
componenttext: Sure. For next year, we've got the continuation of Project Delta and there might be some carryover into fiscal '12 but the bulk of that spending will be behind us as we exit fiscal '11. But the other main reason for the continued higher level of spending is a lot of support of the expansions we talked about. New locations at DeVry University, Chamberlain, Carrington, real estate improvements and expansions at a number of facilities in DeVry University and others. The capacity add that we talked about at Ross. And continued other investments in DeVry Brasil. So all these things add up to spending in this range I would expect it to not maybe be at this level in fiscal '12, but definitely as a percent of revenue, consistent with what its averaged the last two or three years.

componenttext: I think we saw some leverage here but the cost of Educational Services still was growing greater than 20%. So we're investing in our Educational Services pretty significantly. And I think we've been able to, through our utilization of our capacity, been able to get more leverage out of that the past few years. And as I alluded to with the capital spending, I think one of the offshoots of the enrollment growth that we've had is that we need to invest in some of our facilities for expansion and some of our centers that have shown nice growth and enhancements in infrastructure and square footage and some other locations. But we've seen nice improvement in our capacity utilization and our square foot per student that we've been tracking.
