headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2010 Conference Call. My name is Jeremy, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to your host f
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to DeVry's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2010 Conference Call. My name is Jeremy, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Ms. Joan Bates. Joan, you may proceed.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy. With me today from DeVry's senior leadership team are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Before we begin, please be advised that statements made o
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy. With me today from DeVry's senior leadership team are Daniel Hamburger, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rick Gunst, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please be advised that statements made on this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements subject to the Safe Harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements generally can be identified by phrases such as DeVry, Inc. or its management has a view, objective or outlook or that management believes, expects, anticipates, foresees, forecasts, estimates or other words or phrases of similar import. Actual results may differ materially from those projected or implied. Potential risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause results to differ are described more fully in Item 1A, Risk Factors, in DeVry's most recent annual report on Form 10-K for the year ending June 30, 2009, and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on August 26, 2009.
Telephone and webcast replays of the call are available until August 26, 2010. To access the replays, please refer to today's release for information.
Today, Daniel Hamburger will begin the call with a quick overview followed by a financial and operational review by Rick Gunst. Daniel will then provide an update on DeVry's five-year strategic plan before opening up the call for your questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Daniel.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joan, and thanks everyone for joining us today. We're pleased to announce another quarter and another year of strong performance, which has been driven by the continued execution of our diversification strategy that I want to talk about a little b
componenttext:
Thanks, Joan, and thanks everyone for joining us today. We're pleased to announce another quarter and another year of strong performance, which has been driven by the continued execution of our diversification strategy that I want to talk about a little bit more, and by our focus on academic quality and excellent student services. And we of course are in constant dialogue with many of you and we know that you have questions about the notice of proposed rule-making, the NPRM, and the Senate Health Committee activities. So let me make some remarks about these items right up front.
You've seen our comments on Part I of the proposed Rules and we're analyzing Part II. We've been very consistent over many years in not speculating on the outcomes of pending regulation or how it might impact our schools or our program and we're going to stay with that long-standing policy. I caution you not to read anything negative into this approach, because we continue to be very comfortable with the value proposition offered by our program. We deliver programs that lead to employment and long-term careers for our students. Just a few examples that illustrate why we say this. The top five employers of DeVry University graduates over the past five years are Fortune 100 companies like AT&T, Verizon, General Electric, Intel, IBM, all premier companies that need highly skilled employees.
The overall graduation rate for Carrington College in Carrington College of California is greater than 60%. So most of these students are progressing into the workforce within three years. And Chamberlain College of Nursing, well, you know the story there, a high demand field that commands strong salaries. These are just a few examples of why we're very comfortable that our programs lead to a strong return on educational investment for our students.
Now the comment period on Part II of the Gainful Employment Proposal is still open and we haven't submitted our comments yet. One thing I will say is that we continue to believe that robust disclosure is the most important way to help prospective student consumers make informed decisions. We were pleased to see those provisions included in Part I of the proposed rule. Now let me make a few comments on the so-called incentive compensation proposals, and I say so-called as [ph] (17:55) there seems to be a misperception that the current Safe Harbors allow for employment-based bonuses and that the proposed Rules would ban them, and it's just not so. Such payments are already prohibited. 
Now we support the department's efforts to refine regulations and to ensure Congress's intent per the statute is carried out effectively. Consistent with current regulations, we don't pay commissions or bonuses based on enrollment. We pay salaries to all of our employees, who also receive annual performance reviews and are rewarded on merit.
And while we support the department's intentions, we do think there are three points that could further enhance the proposed Rule. First, quantitative performance measurement should be permitted to play at least some part in the judgments that institutions make about base salary adjustments. 
Second, restrictions on compensation practices should apply only to employees directly engaged in enrollment and in awarding financial aid. And third, we should permit compensation that's linked to shared societal and institutional goals like program persistence and graduation. 
Let me also touch briefly on the Senate Health Committee activities. As you know, we were the only private sector organization invited to testify before the Committee to date. We very much appreciated that opportunity to discuss our views with the Committee. We think it's essential that the Committee's going to get a balanced view of the sector for them to hear from institutions like DeVry that have a proven track record of delivering programs that lead to employment and long-term careers for our students. So we'll continue to work constructively with the Committee and the next aspect of that will be pulling together the information that they've asked for.
And so overall, we understand that there are concerns with unaffordable debt level, with the quality of some programs, with the recruiting practices of some personnel at some institutions. But stepping back, let's remember the big picture. We need more quality educational capacity to meet our workforce goals. In fact just this week, the President reemphasized his goal, our goal, our nation's goal of having 8 million more college graduates by 2020. 
Private sector schools play a vital role in adding capacity with quality outcomes at a lower net cost to taxpayers. All schools, private sector, public sector and independent, must be held accountable for quality outcomes and for value. So we support high standards, rigorously and evenly enforced. The key point is that any policy, regulation or legislation must be crafted not only to address problems but to enhance the ability of compliant schools to deliver this much-needed quality educational capacity. We must avoid unintended consequences.
Let's not throw the baby out with the bath water. And so with that sort of overview, I'd like to turn the call over to Rick for a review of DeVry's financial and operational highlights.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon everyone. Well, another fiscal year's come to a close and we are very proud of our strong performance, driven by our focus on academic quality. Full-year revenue hit a record $1.915 billion, up approximately 31% versus p
componenttext:
Thanks, Daniel, and good afternoon everyone. Well, another fiscal year's come to a close and we are very proud of our strong performance, driven by our focus on academic quality. Full-year revenue hit a record $1.915 billion, up approximately 31% versus prior year. Organic revenue growth was about 27% versus prior year, excluding the Carrington and DeVry Brasil acquisitions that occurred last fiscal year. Net income for fiscal 2010 was $280 million, up 63% versus last year, and earnings per share were $3.87, up 64%, excluding last year's discrete items.
Our after-tax income margin for the year was 14.6%, up from 11.3% last year. Over the past 10 years, our after-tax income margin has averaged about 9% with fiscal 2005 as the low point at 2.3%. 
We're real pleased with our performance this year. We will be focusing on our after-tax net income margin as our key margin metric as this accounts for the over $130 million in federal and state income taxes paid during the past year. 
Fourth quarter results were also very strong and reflect strong top line growth, continued operating leverage and a focus on reinvesting the academic quality and long-term growth initiatives. Revenue of $507 million was about 20% versus last year. This was all organic growth as we now overlapped the DeVry Brasil acquisition which occurred April 2009.
Net income of $72 million was up 78% versus last year and earnings per share of $0.99, up 77% excluding last year's discrete items. And our net income margin was 14.1% in the quarter. We referenced fourth quarter results, include expense related to share-based payments of approximately $2.2 million pretax compared to $1 million last year. 
For the full year, share-based expense totaled $10.1 million versus $7.6 million for fiscal 2009. Our overall effective tax rate was 32.2% for the year and 28.6% in the fourth quarter. The full year tax rate was up from the 30.4% tax rate for fiscal 2009, primarily due to the continued increase in domestic source income.
Our fourth quarter rate was lower due to year-end tax true-ups of state tax accruals and reserves. Cost of Educational Services expense increased 23% for the year and student service and administrative expense was up by about 24% for the year. While we're still making investments to drive future growth such as systems improvements, new location and program rollouts and investments in academic quality, we expect expenses to continue to grow at a lower rate than revenue again in fiscal 2011. 
Also for perspective, I'd like to point out that Educational Services expense was 3.7x the amount spent on advertising and marketing for the year. There's a lot of misinformation out there, so I want to be clear, again, that our spending on instruction was 3.7x our advertising and marketing expense.
Now let's move to some of the highlights of our segment results, which are further detailed in our release. The Business, Technology and Management segment had very strong results, with total enrollment up 22%. As expected, new student enrollment has begun to moderate but still up 10% versus the tough comparison in the prior year. As we've stated in the past, our goal is to achieve approximately 20% annual compound earnings growth for DeVry as a whole over the long term. We achieved these results for 40 straight quarters back in the '90s, with enrollment growth of 7.5% on average and expect enrollment growth at DeVry University to return to the high single digits over the long run.
Revenue in the segment was up about 32% versus last year in the quarter and 28% for the fiscal year, driven by continued online expansion and strong on-site enrollments. Segment earnings, which are of course pretax, were up about 140% for the quarter and more than doubled for the year, excluding last year's discrete items, driven primarily by improved operating leverage from the strong enrollment growth.
Persistence at DeVry University improved yet again this quarter, in part because of the success of the Student Central program being implemented across our campus locations. Student Central provides students with a one-stop destination for curricular, career and financial services. We've accelerated the rollout of the program because it's so helpful to our students and it's such a great investment of our resources.
Within the Medical and Healthcare segment, revenue was up 23.5% in the quarter and about 40% for the year. Revenue growth for the year would have been about 33% excluding the impact of the Carrington acquisition. 
The strong revenue growth was driven by strong demand for Chamberlain's nursing program with total enrollment up 65% in the summer. This growth was offset by a modest decline in new students at Carrington during the period as inquiry volume decreased in advance of the name change, and the expected moderation of new student enrollment at Ross University as we make investments in academic quality and capacity. Ross's total enrollment was up 2.1%, which was in line with management's expectations.
Segment earnings were down slightly in the fourth quarter because of startup expenses for the two new Chamberlain locations, which are DeVry University co-locations in Arlington, Virginia and Chicago; also, expenses associated with the Carrington name change and startup costs and investments associated with Carrington's online programs. Segment earnings for the year were up 21%.
Our Professional Education segment results continue to show signs of improvement as revenue was up about 9% in the quarter and up slightly for the year, a nice improvement from the negative trends we've seen the past 18 months or so. 
While some of this growth may be activity in advance of the CPA exam change in calendar 2011, we are encouraged that the negative impact of the economic downturn may be abetting. Segment earnings were down less than 1% in the quarter and down 13% for the year, but the pretax margin for the segment remained above 30%.
Finally, the other Educational Services revenue was up about 15% in the quarter and contributed about $60 million for the year. Advanced Academics had a challenging quarter as school district budget constraints adversely impacted summer school enrollments. DeVry Brasil experienced good revenue growth. Segment earnings for the quarter were only about $400,000 as Advanced Academics revenue softness and investments to drive future enrollment in both operations negatively impacted earnings. These investments included facilities, training programs for academic support at DeVry Brasil, as well as more efficient processes in student financial aid that we've implemented.
Shifting to cash flow and the balance sheet. Cash flow from operations for the year was $392 million versus $250 million last year. These strong cash flow results drove our cash, marketable security and investment balance to $323 million at the end of the fiscal year compared to $225 million last year. This balance includes about $13 million of auction rate securities but this remaining balance was redeemed at par in early July so we no longer own any of these auction rate securities.
We also used our positive cash flow generation to pay off all our outstanding debt. You may recall that we borrowed about $200 million in September 2008 to help fund the U.S. Education, now Carrington, acquisition and ended up paying off all of the debt in less than two years.
Our net accounts receivable balance was about $119 million versus $104 million last year. The increase can be attributed to strong enrollment and revenue growth in the quarter as receivables per account across our schools are generally aligned or lower than prior year. For example, DeVry University accounts receivable per account was down about 17% versus last year thanks to the focus and efforts of our campuses and student services staff. 
Bad debt expense was 2.6% of revenue for fiscal 2010, which is at the lower end of our historical range of 2.5% to 3%. We're very proud of these results, especially given the difficult economic conditions and believe our program's strong value proposition and return on investment contributes to our students' ability to pay off their account balances.
We continue to invest in quality and growth initiatives such as Project Delta, our new student information system. As an update on Project Delta, we've implemented the first major module in the fourth quarter. Overall, it went very well and we're realizing benefits such as improved response time and service to students as well as increased productivity. 
Other investments in quality and growth include facility improvements in new locations at DeVry University, Carrington, Chamberlain and DeVry Brasil, along with investments in facilities and infrastructure improvements at Ross University to support capacity expansion. We will continue to invest a significant portion of our earnings back into operations to improve the student value proposition. As an illustration of this, while we earned about $165 million in fiscal 2009, our capital spending was over $131 million in fiscal 2010.
So this year's earnings fund next year's investments in quality and growth initiatives. We expect capital spending for fiscal 2011 will likely be in the $140 million to $150 million range. Finally, during the quarter, we continued to execute our third share repurchase program. Through June 30, we've repurchased approximately 422,000 shares of our common stock at a total cost of $25.4 million. We've been repurchasing shares more rapidly under our structured plan given the fairly large stock price movements over the past few months, as I know all of you are very aware of, and are over halfway through our $50 million program as of the end of June.
At this pace, we anticipate completing this program well ahead of the December 31, 2011 authorization period, likely by the end of this quarter. As we announced in today's release, DeVry's board has authorized a fourth $50 million program to commence once the existing program is complete so there's no lapse in our programs. Investing in our shares at these levels reflects our belief in the long-term value we're creating. And again, that value is based on delivering value to our students.
Lastly, we anticipate another increase in our effective tax rate next year given the growth in domestic source income, likely up about 200 basis points or so. So after-tax earnings will likely grow at a lower rate than pretax earnings next year. That concludes my overview of the very strong operating and financial results for fiscal 2010. As we look to a new fiscal year, we still feel very comfortable with our long-term financial objective to deliver double-digit revenue growth and roughly 20% compound annual earnings growth over the next few years. 
So with that, let me turn the call back over to Daniel.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. Well done. Recently, we met with our board and they approved our five-year strategic plan so I'd like to spend a few minutes now sharing some highlights. In recent years, we've set out to diversify and transform the organization so that we'r
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. Well done. Recently, we met with our board and they approved our five-year strategic plan so I'd like to spend a few minutes now sharing some highlights. In recent years, we've set out to diversify and transform the organization so that we're positioned well for the future. We've added Advanced Academics, Carrington Colleges and DeVry Brasil to our family of schools over just the past couple of years. We are now much more diversified across curriculum areas and degree levels. We're well positioned to make investments in our future in order to drive academic quality and student outcomes and to take advantage of opportunities to further expand our programs, services and geographic footprint. So how do we take this momentum and all of these positive attributes and focus them to realize our future objectives while helping to solve society's unmet need for high-quality education. Let me walk you through in broad strokes our strategic plan for the next five years.
Now to start, our vision is that DeVry will become the leading global provider of career-oriented Educational Services. We believe this creates value for society and all of our stakeholders by delivering high-quality educational programs that are supported by best in class student services. Our strategy to accomplish this vision can be summed up in just three words: achieve, grow and build. First, we'll achieve superior student outcomes by providing both high-quality education and student services. This is in line with our operating philosophy that "Quality Leads to Growth". 
[Indiscernible] (34:08), as we invest in academic quality, we help students achieve excellent outcomes and we help meet the needs of society and the employers who hire our graduates. This in turn results in better student retention and referrals, and continued enrollment growth, and all of these things generate the financial resources which we reinvest right back into the quality of our programs and services. And so it's a self-reinforcing cycle of sustainable growth. And it all begins with academic quality. An example of this strategy is the Student Central program that's being implemented across all DeVry University campuses and Rick mentioned this earlier. While we've invested nearly $9 million in this initiative, and we've hired approximately 200 additional career services advisors, financial literacy consultants and Student Central personnel. Another example of our strategy at work comes from Becker Professional Education. As you may know, and Rick mentioned earlier this as well, the CPA exam will expand to include a much broader range of subjects for 2011, so in response we're making a major investment in one of Becker's largest redevelopment efforts ever. As a result, all of our programs and materials for the 2011 CPA exam contain the latest information that our students will need to prepare for the new exam. And at Carrington College, by pursuing this strategy of achieving high-quality academic outcomes, eight out of nine eligible campuses qualified for honor roll status.
This was during a reaffirmation of accreditation by Carrington's accreditor ACICS. Given that ACICS awards this honor to less than 20% of its schools, we were very proud to have eight out of nine of our schools. The second strategy is to grow and to diversify into new curriculum areas, degree levels and geography. Chamberlain College of Nursing is expanding locations and launching new programs. The new RN to MSN degree program will respond to the increasing demand for nurses prepared at the Masters level, and through a joint program with DeVry University's Keller Graduate School of Management, Chamberlain is launching an online MSN/MBA program. 
At DeVry Brasil, we're growing by adding 30 new degree programs in the fields of Healthcare, Engineering and IT. These high-demand programs are a tremendous opportunity for us to meet student needs in Brazil. So diversification drives growth and diversification mitigates risk. Because we're less vulnerable to economic cycles and we're not overly dependent in any one program area. In fact, in the back of today's press release, we included some charts showing the progress we've made in our diversification strategy throughout curriculum areas, then there's a chart on degree level and geography. So whereas in 2002, we were 70% Technology programs and zero Healthcare, we're now broadly diversified across Technology, Business and Healthcare curriculum. So achieve student outcome, grow and diversify and, lastly, build a high-quality infrastructure to support our growth and to compete in an increasingly competitive market. This infrastructure comprises four areas: technology, online educational platform, a strong reputation and human resources, HR.
Project Delta is the largest investment we're making in our technology. This large-scale upgrade to DeVry University's and Chamberlain College of Nursing's IT infrastructure will both make our operations more efficient and save our students time that they can use to focus on their studies. Over the past several years, DeVry Online has done an excellent job of providing high-quality centralized services to support DeVry schools. Our strategy is to further leverage this capability at Carrington and by increasing the rate of new program development across all our schools.
The third part of our infrastructure is our reputation, our brand, if you will; what we stand for. When we were building it, it's through [ph] (38:09) increased civic engagement. We're giving back. We recently announced a major partnership with America's Promise Alliance, which was founded by General Colin Powell and with the support of President Obama and Secretary Duncan, the Alliance is focused on solving our country's high school dropout crisis. Over the next three years, DeVry will be donating $1.5 million to the Alliance and making additional in-kind contributions of up to $750,000 per year in each of the 10 cities where the Alliance operates. A key focus of this partnership will be expanding the Advantage Academy dual enrollment model in those cities.
When we announced this partnership, I got emails from across the DeVry family full of excitement and pride. It's emblematic of how DeVry's people are doing well by doing good and that leads me to the fourth element of this growth infrastructure. And that's our human resources.
Our goal is to be the employer of choice in education, and our diversified array of schools offer exceptional career development opportunities for our people. Two recent announcements illustrate this. John Roselli, who will be Becker's new President in the fall, has a tremendous foundation [indiscernible] (39:23) to build upon thanks to the work of his predecessor, Tom Vucinic, whom I personally would like to thank for his many years of exceptional service to DeVry. And also this fall, Steven Riehs will become President of a new organizational structure that will include Advanced Academics, Becker Professional Education, DeVry Brasil and our overall international business development efforts. But part of this HR infrastructure is our culture. DeVry's culture has always been founded on quality and integrity. And so when I think of building the growth infrastructure, I think of building a house. You don't build it from the top down. You start with the foundation, the infrastructure, so that as you build and grow, you're on a solid foundation. 
And so that's our strategy, achieve superior student outcomes through academic quality and student services, grow and diversify into new program areas, levels and geographies and build a high-quality infrastructure to support our growth.
We're heading into next year, into this new fiscal '11 for us. Our priorities are aligned with this strategy. And these are, first, achieving our academic quality goals, including exam results, higher retention and graduation rates as well as expanded student services. Second, in the grow category, expanding our Healthcare programs and locations to address the strong demand for medical professionals, expanding our Becker Professional Education segment into markets, continuing to develop internationally with DeVry Brasil, strengthening our high school programs while increasing synergies between Advanced Academics and our postsecondary schools. And in the build category, continuing to roll out Project Delta, continuing to develop our new online programs and strengthening our talent development and succession planning. So that's our strategy. 
And lastly, I'd like to take a moment to thank the more than 17,000 employees at DeVry who are helping to empower our students to achieve their educational and career goals. We delivered a very strong year of academic results in fiscal 2010 and it was due to their focus on our students. 
So with that, we'd be happy to take any questions. Joan?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel. I'm very happy to let everyone know that joining us for the Q&A portion of the call today is Sharon Thomas-Parrott, DeVry's Senior Vice President of Government & Regulatory Affairs and our Chief Compliance Officer. So Jeremy, you'll give o
componenttext: Thanks, Daniel. I'm very happy to let everyone know that joining us for the Q&A portion of the call today is Sharon Thomas-Parrott, DeVry's Senior Vice President of Government & Regulatory Affairs and our Chief Compliance Officer. So Jeremy, you'll give our callers the instructions on asking questions and we'll begin.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question will be from the line of Bob Craig with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question will be from the line of Bob Craig with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: A question for you on the regulatory environment and perhaps changing economic environment. Have either caused any meaningful changes in your mind in terms of how you approach the growth agenda or spending plans for fiscal '11?
componenttext: A question for you on the regulatory environment and perhaps changing economic environment. Have either caused any meaningful changes in your mind in terms of how you approach the growth agenda or spending plans for fiscal '11?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I would say no. I would say that we continue to invest in quality initiatives and in growth initiatives and that's really driven by the demand for career-oriented education that we see, so that has not been impacted by the regulatory environment. You
componenttext: Bob, I would say no. I would say that we continue to invest in quality initiatives and in growth initiatives and that's really driven by the demand for career-oriented education that we see, so that has not been impacted by the regulatory environment. You mentioned the economic environment, that remains to be seen. It is, I would say that's a bit of an open question.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, your comments on new students. Certainly understand the tougher comparisons, but the rate of slowdown was a little bit greater than what we had anticipated. Perhaps that's just our fault but how did new students on the DeVry undergrad side compare w
componenttext: Rick, your comments on new students. Certainly understand the tougher comparisons, but the rate of slowdown was a little bit greater than what we had anticipated. Perhaps that's just our fault but how did new students on the DeVry undergrad side compare with your plan and were there any unusual trends that develop by curriculum area or by credential level?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: We said all along that we don't anticipate being able to sustain new student, or for that matter total student growth rate at these levels into the future. So the fact that we're overlapping 20 and high teens growth, we can't continue to grow at those lev
componenttext: We said all along that we don't anticipate being able to sustain new student, or for that matter total student growth rate at these levels into the future. So the fact that we're overlapping 20 and high teens growth, we can't continue to grow at those levels for the sustainable future and as I said in my remarks, we anticipate leveling off in the high single digits over the long run. So this period having 10% new student growth and 22% total student growth is still above those long-term trends, and it's not out of line with what we expected.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And Bob, I'll just add one more piece of color on that, and it sort of ties back to the previous question you asked me about the economy. I mean, DeVry overall, the DeVry family, is really much less countercyclical than a lot of people think. We've talked
componenttext: And Bob, I'll just add one more piece of color on that, and it sort of ties back to the previous question you asked me about the economy. I mean, DeVry overall, the DeVry family, is really much less countercyclical than a lot of people think. We've talked about that. The diversified strategy allows us to grow throughout good and bad economic cycles. And then the other piece, to your question to Rick about the new student results, one of the things that we noticed at DeVry University specifically where you're asking was a very nice balance across Business and Technology programs. And you remember, a few years ago that wasn't the case and the Technology was struggling a little bit. And it's been the case for a good period of time now, nice steady growth in both the Technology as well as in the Business programs.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question will be from the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And your next question will be from the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Quick question on gainful employment. I know that you're not commenting on the potential impact given that it's not finalized yet, but I'm just wondering, have you internally been able to assess the impact of the proposed rule?
componenttext: Quick question on gainful employment. I know that you're not commenting on the potential impact given that it's not finalized yet, but I'm just wondering, have you internally been able to assess the impact of the proposed rule?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, to some extent we have. Of course we don't have all the data at this point. But we have certainly been busy doing as much analysis as we can. But that's internal. I just learned a long time ago that answering hypothetical questions is just nev
componenttext: Sure. Well, to some extent we have. Of course we don't have all the data at this point. But we have certainly been busy doing as much analysis as we can. But that's internal. I just learned a long time ago that answering hypothetical questions is just never a good idea.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. But you've got enough that you're comfortable with the type of impact it might have.
componenttext: Okay. But you've got enough that you're comfortable with the type of impact it might have.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: What I'm saying is we're comfortable that we provide a high-quality value proposition for our students, which is what this whole thing is aimed at making sure that schools are doing. So we're very comparable with the value proposition and the employment a
componenttext: What I'm saying is we're comfortable that we provide a high-quality value proposition for our students, which is what this whole thing is aimed at making sure that schools are doing. So we're very comparable with the value proposition and the employment and the career results that our students are achieving across all our schools.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. In terms of undergraduate and new student enrollment trends, I'm wondering, was there anything done in terms of slowing your advertising spend and what happened to the cost to acquire a student in the term?
componenttext: Okay. In terms of undergraduate and new student enrollment trends, I'm wondering, was there anything done in terms of slowing your advertising spend and what happened to the cost to acquire a student in the term?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: No real major trends to report there in terms of marketing spend. And so pretty steady as she goes there in terms of the expense per new student.
componenttext: No real major trends to report there in terms of marketing spend. And so pretty steady as she goes there in terms of the expense per new student.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Amy Junker with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Amy Junker with Robert W. Baird.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Daniel, can you just talk a little bit about, with a little more color perhaps on Carrington? We saw a little continued deceleration from what we saw last quarter in terms of starts, and I know you talked about some of that was due to the name change. But
componenttext: Daniel, can you just talk a little bit about, with a little more color perhaps on Carrington? We saw a little continued deceleration from what we saw last quarter in terms of starts, and I know you talked about some of that was due to the name change. But do you think that there was any lingering impact from the capacity or execution issues that you talked about last quarter?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I do, and I think we deserve any criticism that you might want to heap upon us on that. We did have some internal execution issues there during that implementation period of the name change. That turned out to be a major, major project, very resource-inte
componenttext: I do, and I think we deserve any criticism that you might want to heap upon us on that. We did have some internal execution issues there during that implementation period of the name change. That turned out to be a major, major project, very resource-intensive, executed very well. It just I think took a little bit more resource and maybe we took our eye off the ball a little bit on our day-to-day execution in the process. Now having said that, and as we look at the result of it and what we see now, we do see a very good acceptance of the name in the marketplace. We're seeing of late the inquiry volume coming back and so we don't have an overarching concern, with a capital C, it was really more executionally driven. So there's still good demand, out in the marketplace there's a huge need, an unmet need for career-focused education in the career college area and healthcare-focused programs that Carrington Colleges schools provide. So I think it really was more of our own internal execution and nobody's more upset about that than we are.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: So do you think that the start growth can turn back positive in the current quarter? Or is that something that it may still be another quarter before we see that turn in the right direction?
componenttext: So do you think that the start growth can turn back positive in the current quarter? Or is that something that it may still be another quarter before we see that turn in the right direction?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it certainly can. There's nothing that would preclude that.
componenttext: No, it certainly can. There's nothing that would preclude that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to Ross, could you just talk a little bit about the impact from the new rules that are being proposed for U.S. aid to students at foreign institutions? I know that some of the rules are talking about raising the percentage of graduates that m
componenttext: With respect to Ross, could you just talk a little bit about the impact from the new rules that are being proposed for U.S. aid to students at foreign institutions? I know that some of the rules are talking about raising the percentage of graduates that must pass the U.S. Medical License Exam. I know you guys have very good metrics on that but can you just maybe talk a minute about what if any impact that would have on Ross?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, and again, the overarching comment is until the rules are finalized, we can't and won't speculate on the impact to DeVry on its programs, students and so forth. But you're right, the sort of 75% benchmark is out there, and the USMLE Step 1 pass rate
componenttext: Sure, and again, the overarching comment is until the rules are finalized, we can't and won't speculate on the impact to DeVry on its programs, students and so forth. But you're right, the sort of 75% benchmark is out there, and the USMLE Step 1 pass rates for Ross University School of Medicine students are well over 90%. So that just gives you an indication and a feel for how we might view that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question's from the line of Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question's from the line of Jeff Silber with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back on Ross. In the press release you talk about moderating new enrollment growth while the initiatives are completed. Do you have some sort of time frame when that will be done?
componenttext: Just to circle back on Ross. In the press release you talk about moderating new enrollment growth while the initiatives are completed. Do you have some sort of time frame when that will be done?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we've said, it'll be at least through January here, and we'll keep you posted as we go. Some of this is within our own control and we take responsibility for that. Some of them are outside our control and we just have to work through the regulator
componenttext: Yes. As we've said, it'll be at least through January here, and we'll keep you posted as we go. Some of this is within our own control and we take responsibility for that. Some of them are outside our control and we just have to work through the regulatory, the accreditation processes. So until we have more capacity, we're going to do the right thing for our students and limit the enrollment growth to that which we can support and continue to maintain and enhance the quality educational outcomes.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could switch gears to Chamberlain, you had some phenomenal growth numbers. Is it possible to break out just same-school growth both in terms of new enrollment and total enrollment? And I'm just also wondering how placement trends are for those school
componenttext: If I could switch gears to Chamberlain, you had some phenomenal growth numbers. Is it possible to break out just same-school growth both in terms of new enrollment and total enrollment? And I'm just also wondering how placement trends are for those schools?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, for Chamberlain, in terms of placement -- and by the way if you'll forgive me, Jeff, we like to use the word employment results, and it's very important, it's not just trying to be cute or anything, and words matter. But we're very adamant internall
componenttext: Sure, for Chamberlain, in terms of placement -- and by the way if you'll forgive me, Jeff, we like to use the word employment results, and it's very important, it's not just trying to be cute or anything, and words matter. But we're very adamant internally and externally when we talk to our teams and we talk to students. We don't place graduates. We provide them with the skills to conduct a lifelong career search. In today's world, most of us will go through career changes more than one time. So we make sure that we educate students on how to conduct a job search, and they go and get that job, we don't place them. So we like to use the word employment statistics or graduate employment statistics. And they're strong at Chamberlain. Obviously, there's a lot of need and that's only going to grow for nursing graduates. And in terms of the growth, I'm not able to break that out in terms of a same campus, new campus online, we just haven't broken that out yet.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next, you have the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.
componenttext: And next, you have the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple questions on the margins. First of all in the Professional business with the revenue I think stabilized and I guess quite a bit better than stabilized this quarter, is it reasonable to expect the profitability to continue to decline there
componenttext: I guess a couple questions on the margins. First of all in the Professional business with the revenue I think stabilized and I guess quite a bit better than stabilized this quarter, is it reasonable to expect the profitability to continue to decline there as you're making investments? Or is there some change in the business model? Or would it be reasonable to expect that margins might start to flatten out if you continue to have positive revenue there?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gary, hi, it's Rick. As we look forward to this fiscal year, we don't expect robust improvement on the top line but we hope that we'd see some growth on the top line and likewise at the bottom line. And margins being about flat, would be I guess our
componenttext: Yes, Gary, hi, it's Rick. As we look forward to this fiscal year, we don't expect robust improvement on the top line but we hope that we'd see some growth on the top line and likewise at the bottom line. And margins being about flat, would be I guess our general perspective on that.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the DeVry University segment, another incredible performance on the margins and the incremental operating margin. I guess it seems reasonable that revenue growth could decelerate quite a bit but you probably still have pretty healthy incremental ma
componenttext: And on the DeVry University segment, another incredible performance on the margins and the incremental operating margin. I guess it seems reasonable that revenue growth could decelerate quite a bit but you probably still have pretty healthy incremental margins. Is that the right way to think about it and we've got some more margin gains in store? Are there any sort of big, big investments that you're planning to layer on that might really decelerate the pace of the gains in the next few quarters?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we will continue to have margin improvement in that segment but not at the same level by any means that we've seen this past year in fiscal '10 or fiscal '09 for that matter because as you mentioned the top line growth will begin to slow dow
componenttext: Well, I think we will continue to have margin improvement in that segment but not at the same level by any means that we've seen this past year in fiscal '10 or fiscal '09 for that matter because as you mentioned the top line growth will begin to slow down, still be very robust but not be as strong as it was this past year, and the one major investment that will start to realize the expense probably would be the Project Delta. The depreciation and the training costs we're going to have in fiscal '11 will be hitting, a good portion of those costs hit DeVry University or the Business, Technology and Management segment directly. But still with all that, we would expect to see our expenses grow at a slower pace than the top line growth and see margin improvement next year, just not the same level of improvement that we saw, the dramatic improvement this year.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one last question. I understand the desire to grow and diversify and I think it's the right strategy, but adding $50 million to the buyback given how weak the stock has been and how strong your balance sheet and cash flows are, it just doesn
componenttext: And then just one last question. I understand the desire to grow and diversify and I think it's the right strategy, but adding $50 million to the buyback given how weak the stock has been and how strong your balance sheet and cash flows are, it just doesn't really move the needle. I guess I wondered, Daniel, if you could speak on behalf of the board sort of why not consider being more aggressive given that you've got an awful lot of cash to deploy in M&A or other strategies as well?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are mindful of all the potential uses of cash and we are DeVry, remember. So there is a conservative Midwest attitude here that has served us very well over the long term. And we've been criticized many times in the short-term. But over the long-
componenttext: Well, we are mindful of all the potential uses of cash and we are DeVry, remember. So there is a conservative Midwest attitude here that has served us very well over the long term. And we've been criticized many times in the short-term. But over the long-term, people usually say, "Oh, now I get it." So yes, there are acquisition opportunities, there are investment opportunities in quality and growth initiatives. And then certainly, there is money still left in the third share repurchase program and now here launching a fourth in four years, our board felt was appropriate, so it's actually more than $50 million going forward. But the main thing is yes, the intent of it – and maybe we weren't successful in demonstrating that to you – but you should know, the sentiment behind it was as Rick said earlier, that we certainly believe in making that investment in those shares at these levels.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess I would add, Gary, that if you look at this program we're currently almost more than halfway completed, the third program, that was authorized just several months ago and it was supposed to last for two years, but we have it on a structured pr
componenttext: And I guess I would add, Gary, that if you look at this program we're currently almost more than halfway completed, the third program, that was authorized just several months ago and it was supposed to last for two years, but we have it on a structured program so that we're buying back more shares as the price fluctuates down and thanks to all the negative cloud that's been out there, we've been more active in the market and that's why we're going to be completed with this third program likely in another month or so. And so the board authorized another $50 million and we'll maybe, if things don't move we'll complete that quicker and that doesn't mean that they can't add another one on top of that. So I wouldn't read into the $50 million anything more than it's just a continuation of the program and we'll be buying back more at these attractive levels.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next we have Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.
componenttext: And next we have Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I think one of the huge highlights here is how much persistence has soared and Daniel, of course, I heard your original comments of why that's happening with Student Central. My question is about sustainability. Do you feel like the next few semesters sho
componenttext: I think one of the huge highlights here is how much persistence has soared and Daniel, of course, I heard your original comments of why that's happening with Student Central. My question is about sustainability. Do you feel like the next few semesters should have a similar rise in persistence? And how far do you think we are along in benefiting from the effects of Student Central?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well thanks, Andrew, for those comments. We're very proud of that increase in persistence. That's what we're here for, to support our students and help them to persist through to graduation. And especially for many of the students that we serve in many of
componenttext: Well thanks, Andrew, for those comments. We're very proud of that increase in persistence. That's what we're here for, to support our students and help them to persist through to graduation. And especially for many of the students that we serve in many of our schools, who are often first in their family to go to college, and you think about it, came from a family that was very fortunate, you were going to college and there's a big support network there. That's not America today. There's many, many students who don't have that support network. And so we have to provide that level of support and we have made a huge investment in providing those kinds of support services, and that's going to continue. And I can say that the improvements that we've seen is not the end of our goals. Our goals are still higher. So I can't predict in the near term exactly what that translates to but I can tell you that we do aim higher in that regard.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Right, but Daniel, just speak again. I mean, this semester was just such a large rise. I mean, by my calculations it was actually the largest year-over-year rise that DeVry has seen going years back. Do you feel like that type of rise in any way is an ano
componenttext: Right, but Daniel, just speak again. I mean, this semester was just such a large rise. I mean, by my calculations it was actually the largest year-over-year rise that DeVry has seen going years back. Do you feel like that type of rise in any way is an anomaly or do you feel like that's in general how we're entering the fall semester, for example?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think it's an anomaly or sort of an accident. It's due to a lot of hard work on the part of our professors and all of our people. And I don't think it's going to just sort of poof and then go away. I think we're going to continue to be persis
componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's an anomaly or sort of an accident. It's due to a lot of hard work on the part of our professors and all of our people. And I don't think it's going to just sort of poof and then go away. I think we're going to continue to be persistent in improving persistence.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: So you think it's going to be a theme in the current fiscal year?
componenttext: So you think it's going to be a theme in the current fiscal year?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a huge theme and it's job one in our strategy. That is the strategy number one, achieving our high-quality academic outcomes in student services is all in support of persistence, and it's important to recognize this is [ph] (59:40) academic quality a
componenttext: It's a huge theme and it's job one in our strategy. That is the strategy number one, achieving our high-quality academic outcomes in student services is all in support of persistence, and it's important to recognize this is [ph] (59:40) academic quality and student services. We have to match the excellence in the classroom with excellence in all of the surrounding services that go around that. And it's a combination of both. World-class customer service, which is not something that you get from many public sector universities and others. That is the winning formula.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And next you have the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.
componenttext: And next you have the line of Corey Greendale with First Analysis.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: First, a couple of quick numbers questions. Last quarter I believe you said that you thought 20% EPS growth in fiscal '11 was reasonable. Is that still your thinking?
componenttext: First, a couple of quick numbers questions. Last quarter I believe you said that you thought 20% EPS growth in fiscal '11 was reasonable. Is that still your thinking?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said at the end of my comments, Corey, looking at 20% earnings growth, the challenge might be that given the increase in our tax rate that we anticipate given the fact that our domestic source income will be growing faster than the international
componenttext: Yes, as I said at the end of my comments, Corey, looking at 20% earnings growth, the challenge might be that given the increase in our tax rate that we anticipate given the fact that our domestic source income will be growing faster than the international income because Ross will be flattish, even down. That puts a little pressure on the EPS number but operating income should be still in that 20% range.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the thought about high single-digit growth at DeVry University, you're talking about overall enrollment, right, not necessarily new student enrollment?
componenttext: And in terms of the thought about high single-digit growth at DeVry University, you're talking about overall enrollment, right, not necessarily new student enrollment?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, over time, new students and total student growth tends to come together. That period I mentioned in the '90s was 7.5% for new student growth and 7.5% of total student growth. So as it works through the pipeline it tends to equilibrate.
componenttext: Well, over time, new students and total student growth tends to come together. That period I mentioned in the '90s was 7.5% for new student growth and 7.5% of total student growth. So as it works through the pipeline it tends to equilibrate.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering, if you look over the next couple of terms, the comps get tougher on the new student enrollments. I'm just wondering if people should be keeping that in mind and looking for a deceleration over the next couple terms in that metric from
componenttext: I'm just wondering, if you look over the next couple of terms, the comps get tougher on the new student enrollments. I'm just wondering if people should be keeping that in mind and looking for a deceleration over the next couple terms in that metric from what you just reported?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't give guidance in that regard but as you start to level off in that, we've been doing better than that for the past many quarters and periods; wouldn't be surprised if maybe we dip a little bit below. But again, the good news is given our p
componenttext: Again, we don't give guidance in that regard but as you start to level off in that, we've been doing better than that for the past many quarters and periods; wouldn't be surprised if maybe we dip a little bit below. But again, the good news is given our persistence that we just talked about, and our strong pipeline of new students we've had over the past several semesters, that should help our total enrollment growth that drives our total revenues.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: And then another topic. DeVry certainly has a good reputation in the industry. Could you just talk about what controls you have in place to ensure that none of your admissions personnel are misrepresenting anything to students and how confident are you th
componenttext: And then another topic. DeVry certainly has a good reputation in the industry. Could you just talk about what controls you have in place to ensure that none of your admissions personnel are misrepresenting anything to students and how confident are you that those controls are preventing any such misrepresentation?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take that, Corey. Thanks for that question. DeVry does have a very robust multilayered compliance program. We've had that for years and decades. The details of it go far beyond the time that we have available on this call. And although we know
componenttext: Sure, I'll take that, Corey. Thanks for that question. DeVry does have a very robust multilayered compliance program. We've had that for years and decades. The details of it go far beyond the time that we have available on this call. And although we know our compliance program is very effective overall, we also know that exceptions can occur. That's true for any organization. So what's equally important is what we do when an error occurs or a problem occurs. And the answer is we take immediate corrective action. We walk the walk and we talk the talk on that. Many examples and we talk about that explicitly within DeVry as part of continuing to maintain and enhance our culture of accountability and integrity. An example, several years ago we became aware of an issue at one camp that related to this and once we investigated it, we promptly notified the Department of Education and terminated the employees who were responsible in that case. And so we do the right thing and we deal with it and I think that's what any organization has to do. I was at a meeting of business leaders a couple of months ago and Jeff Immelt of GE was there and he said, "Look, I got 250,000 employees. I can guarantee you as sure as we're sitting here, 25 or 30 of them are doing something that I don't want them to be doing. The key is making sure that's an exception but also making sure what you do about it when it happens." So these things can happen. But the key is how you deal with that and the key is how do you make sure you've got an overarching training and compliance program to ensure that, that is very much the exception and not the norm.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to Carrington, last quarter, I know you talked about the execution issues impacting starts, but you also talked about countercyclicality, which is not something that you mentioned this quarter. Can you just address what role you think that is
componenttext: With respect to Carrington, last quarter, I know you talked about the execution issues impacting starts, but you also talked about countercyclicality, which is not something that you mentioned this quarter. Can you just address what role you think that is playing? And maybe with hindsight even what role it played last quarter? And how you think about that overall? And then actually related to that, in response to Amy's question, you said you think starts growth can reaccelerate. My question is, do you think it will reaccelerate in this coming quarter?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kelly, and if we've been a little bit, and I've been a little bit wishy-washy on that, I would accept that criticism because it is a little hard to read the tea leaves of the economy right now. Looked like it was getting better and now, just today we
componenttext: Yes, Kelly, and if we've been a little bit, and I've been a little bit wishy-washy on that, I would accept that criticism because it is a little hard to read the tea leaves of the economy right now. Looked like it was getting better and now, just today we had new unemployment claims go up again. So everybody's getting all squirrely about the economy and worried about that, and might that have a countercyclical tailwind, reemergence for those kinds of programs at Carrington. Again, for the DeVry family overall, not really countercyclical; but for Carrington specifically, yes, a little bit countercyclical. And at the same time we've had internal things going on, so it's been a little tough for us to get as strong of a read on that as we normally would because we have data points clouding our instrumentation here. The thing that is particular to us is this name change. We do think that's going to be strong for us. The early read is a very positive response to that and an increase in inquiries from prospective students. So yes, it's possible, and certainly that's what we're working toward, is to turn that around and get the positive new student and of course maintain total student enrollment growth at Carrington Colleges Group.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't fully understand. I mean on the countercyclicality thing, do you think it played a role in the past couple quarters or not? I understand broadly it could play a role and it is a bit uncertain but I mean, looking at the past two quarters, did it pl
componenttext: I don't fully understand. I mean on the countercyclicality thing, do you think it played a role in the past couple quarters or not? I understand broadly it could play a role and it is a bit uncertain but I mean, looking at the past two quarters, did it play a role in your view or not?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: What I'm saying is that over the past period of time, we had a countercyclical tailwind at Carrington. Yes, we had that. And what we said last time, we're starting to see that probably begin to flag. And I still say that, I don't think you're going to see
componenttext: What I'm saying is that over the past period of time, we had a countercyclical tailwind at Carrington. Yes, we had that. And what we said last time, we're starting to see that probably begin to flag. And I still say that, I don't think you're going to see it quite as strong as it was in the depths of the great  recession. And all I'm adding to that is, at the same time we have our own internal execution issues on the negative side, plus we've got the name change on the positive side, so that's three factors all sort of merging together. When you have that, it makes it a little bit more difficult to read. And so I accept that we haven't been crystal clear as we usually like to be on that, but overall that would be the way we characterize it.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you guys please address just how you're looking at pricing on a go-forward basis? Any change to whatever you've spoken in the past with regard to how you think about it?
componenttext: Could you guys please address just how you're looking at pricing on a go-forward basis? Any change to whatever you've spoken in the past with regard to how you think about it?

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, not really, no. The way we look at tuition and the pricing is from at least two lenses. One is the competitive set and our schools often compete actually a lot less with other publicly held organizations that you might be very familiar with and muc
componenttext: Scott, not really, no. The way we look at tuition and the pricing is from at least two lenses. One is the competitive set and our schools often compete actually a lot less with other publicly held organizations that you might be very familiar with and much more so with many of the publicly sector institutions, state schools, and at Carrington it might be at the community college level, for example. And so we look at the competitive tuition increases that are out there and we've certainly seeing pretty big numbers; here in Illinois, I think like 11%, and I've seen mid-teens, even in California over 30% tuition increases. And so that certainly puts one perspective on it. Like in any endeavor in life, you look at what the competitors and what the others are doing. And then the other lens that we put on it is more internal, looking at our programs and the value proposition that our students receive. And so we've I think previously shared ROI, or ROE, our return an educational investment for our students. We've shared how over a 30 year period of time, if you take a look at the salaries that our graduates achieved, the kind of return on investments that they get, even with paying the tuition that they pay. And that's for many of our schools in the high 20s, even over 30% return on investment. Again, other than DeVry shares I'm not sure what else I could find that would have such a high return on investment. So we look at it from both those perspectives and that continues, no change there.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to CapEx, looks like the guidance for next year up $10 million to $20 million year-over-year. Not taking this too far out but is that going to be an unusually high year or is this consistent on the trend? And what are the components that are t
componenttext: With regard to CapEx, looks like the guidance for next year up $10 million to $20 million year-over-year. Not taking this too far out but is that going to be an unusually high year or is this consistent on the trend? And what are the components that are taking us higher? Is it primarily stuff in the Caribbean or Project Delta? Rick, could you just give us a little elaboration? Thanks.

headline: DeVry, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. For next year, we've got the continuation of Project Delta and there might be some carryover into fiscal '12 but the bulk of that spending will be behind us as we exit fiscal '11. But the other main reason for the continued higher level of spending
componenttext: Sure. For next year, we've got the continuation of Project Delta and there might be some carryover into fiscal '12 but the bulk of that spending will be behind us as we exit fiscal '11. But the other main reason for the continued higher level of spending is a lot of support of the expansions we talked about. New locations at DeVry University, Chamberlain, Carrington, real estate improvements and expansions at a number of facilities in DeVry University and others. The capacity add that we talked about at Ross. And continued other investments in DeVry Brasil. So all these things add up to spending in this range I would expect it to not maybe be at this level in fiscal '12, but definitely as a percent of revenue, consistent with what its averaged the last two or three years.

componenttext: I think we saw some leverage here but the cost of Educational Services still was growing greater than 20%. So we're investing in our Educational Services pretty significantly. And I think we've been able to, through our utilization of our capacity, been able to get more leverage out of that the past few years. And as I alluded to with the capital spending, I think one of the offshoots of the enrollment growth that we've had is that we need to invest in some of our facilities for expansion and some of our centers that have shown nice growth and enhancements in infrastructure and square footage and some other locations. But we've seen nice improvement in our capacity utilization and our square foot per student that we've been tracking.
